|sectio = ''[[List of Quercus species#Section Quercus|Quercus]]''
|species = '''''Q. lobata'''''
|binomial = ''Quercus lobata''
|binomial_authority = [[Luis Née|Née]] 1801<ref>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/8009579#page/278/mode/1up Née, Luis 1801. Anales de Ciencias Naturales 3(9): 277–278] diagnosis in Latin, description in Spanish</ref>
|range_map =  Quercus lobata range map 1.png
|range_map_caption = Natural range of ''Quercus lobata''
|synonyms_ref=<ref>[http://www.theplantlist.org/tpl1.1/record/kew-173674 The Plant List, ''Quercus lobata'' Née ]</ref>
|synonyms={{collapsible list|bullets = true
|''Quercus hindsiana'' <small>Benth. ex Dippel</small>
|''Quercus hindsii'' <small>Benth.</small>
|''Quercus longiglanda'' <small>Torr. & Frém.</small>
|''Quercus lyrata'' <small>Spreng. 1826 not Walter 1788</small>
|}}}}

'''''Quercus lobata''''', commonly called the '''valley oak''' or '''roble''', grows into the largest of North American [[oak]]s. It is [[Endemism|endemic]] to [[California]], growing in interior valleys and foothills from [[Siskiyou County]] to [[San Diego County]].<ref name=h>[http://www.calflora.org/cgi-bin/species_query.cgi?where-taxon=Quercus+lobata CalFlora taxon report, University of California: ''Quercus lobata'' (valley oak)]</ref> Mature specimens may attain an age of up to 600 years. This [[deciduous]] oak requires year-round access to [[groundwater]].<ref>Pavlik, B. M., Muick, P., Johnson, S., & Popper, M. (1992). Oaks of California. Cachuma Press ISBN 0-9628505-1-9</ref><ref>Sawyer, John O., & Keeler-Wolf, Todd. (1995) A manual of California Vegetation. California Native Plant Society, page 312.</ref>

Its thick, ridged bark is characteristic and resembles [[alligator]] hide. The valley oak's deeply lobed leaves assist in identification.

==Description and ecology==
The sturdy trunk of the valley oak may exceed three meters (10 feet) in diameter and its stature may surpass 30 meters (100 feet) in height. The "Fetzer Oak", in [[Covelo, California]], is the tallest known North American oak, at {{convert|153|ft|m}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.americanforests.org/bigtree/valley-oak-quercus-lobata-6/|title=American Forests|publisher=americanforests.org|accessdate=2015-12-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pressdemocrat.com/csp/mediapool/sites/PressDemocrat/News/story.csp?cid=2108232&sid=555&fid=181|title=Towering tree on Fetzer ranch has inspired awe for centuries|accessdate=2015-12-21}}</ref>

The branches have an irregular, spreading and arching appearance that produce a profound leafless silhouette in the clear winter sky. During Autumn leaves turn a yellow to light orange color but become brown during mid to late fall. In advancing age the branches assume a drooping characteristic. Its pewter-colored rippled bark adds to the attractive aesthetic of this species.<ref name=tammy>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=233501056 Flora of North America: ''Quercus lobata'']</ref>

[[Image:Valleyoakte.jpg|thumb|left|220px|Close up of trunk fork and bark]]

Typically, leaves are five to ten centimeters (2-4 inches) long and are roundly and deeply lobed. The leaf width is approximately one half its length. Each leaf is matte green with an underneath pale green appearance; moreover, the leaf is covered with abundant soft fuzz, yielding an almost velvety feeling. When a fresh leaf is rubbed or broken, an [[aromatic]] scent is exuded, evoking a forest [[odor]]. The wood is a dull brown approaching yellow, and it has not been used extensively for milling.<ref name=tammy/><ref name=USDA>{{cite web|last1=Howard|first1=Janet L.|title=Quercus lobata|url=http://www.fs.fed.us/database/feis/plants/tree/quelob/all.html|website=Fire Effects Information System, [Online].|publisher=U.S. Department of Agriculture, Forest Service,  Rocky Mountain Research Station, Fire Sciences Laboratory|accessdate=7 September 2014|date=1992}}</ref>

[[Image:Quercus lobata size.jpg|thumb|right|150px|Acorn and leaves]]

Over most of the range, acorns fall in October. A variety of [[mammals]] and [[bird]]s eat them, including the [[acorn woodpecker]], [[California scrub jay]], [[yellow-billed magpie]], and [[California ground squirrel]].<ref name=fs>[http://www.fs.fed.us/database/feis/plants/tree/quelob/all.html US Forest Service Fire Ecology]</ref> The acorns are also attacked by [[Bean weevil|bruchid]] beetles, but can survive moderate levels of infestation.<ref name=acron>{{Cite journal | last = Hobbs | first = T. |author2=T.P. Young   | title = Growing Valley Oak | journal = Ecological Restoration  | volume = 19 | pages = 165–171 | year = 2001}}</ref> Surviving acorns all germinate in their first winter, and none remain by mid-winter. The acorns are medium to dark brown and range from two to three centimeters (0.8-1.2 inches) in length. The caps have deep stippling and are found most often as singlets, but occasionally as doublets. The [[Maidu#Local divisions|Concow tribe]] call the acorns '''lō-ē’''' ([[Konkow language]]).<ref>{{cite book|last1=Chesnut | first1 =Victor King |title=Plants used by the Indians of Mendocino County, California|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vLkUAAAAYAAJ|accessdate=24 August 2012|year=1902|publisher=[[United States Government Printing Office|Government Printing Office]]|page = 406}}</ref>

Globular [[gall]]s up to several centimeters in diameter are frequently attached to twigs of mature specimens of valley oak. These house the [[larval]] stage of small indigenous [[wasp]]s ''[[Andricus quercuscalifornicus]]''.  A related wasp species, ''[[Andricus kingi|A. kingi]]'', produces small galls shaped like Hershey's kisses on leaf surfaces. The valley oak is the only known food plant of ''[[Chionodes petalumensis]]'' [[caterpillar]]s.

Like many oaks, valley oaks can tolerate wild fires. Although smaller individuals may be top-killed, most resprout from the root crown<ref name=Fire>{{Cite journal | last = Holmes | first = K.A. |author2=K.E. Veblen |author3=A.M. Berry |author4=T.P. Young  | title = Effects of prescribed fires on planted valley oak saplings at a research restoration site in the Sacramento Valley | journal = Restoration Ecology  | volume = 19 | pages = in press | year = 2011 | doi=10.1111/j.1526-100x.2009.00529.x}}</ref>

==Distribution and habitat==
Valley oak tolerates cool wet winters and hot dry summers, but requires abundant water. It is most abundant in rich deep soils of valley floors below 600 meters (2000 feet) in elevation. Valley oak is found in dense [[riparian]] forests, open [[foothill woodland]]s and valley [[savanna]]s. Commonly associated trees are [[coast live oak]], [[interior live oak]], [[blue oak]], [[black walnut]], [[California sycamore]] and [[gray pine]].<ref name=j>Griffin, J. R., & Critchfield, W. B. (1972). The Distribution of Forest Trees in California. Berkeley: Pacific Southwest Forest Station and Range Experiment Station, United States Department of Agriculture</ref>

The valley oak is widely distributed in: the California [[Central Valley (California)|Central Valley]]; many smaller valleys such as the [[San Fernando Valley]] (original Spanish place-name from [[California oak woodland|oak savannah]]), [[Conejo Valley]], and [[Santa Ynez Valley]]; the [[Inner Coast Ranges]] south of the [[Eel River (California)|Eel River]]; and the [[Transverse Ranges]] from the [[Tehachapi Mountains]] to the [[Simi Hills]], [[Santa Susana Mountains]]. It is also present on [[Santa Cruz Island]] and [[Santa Catalina Island, California|Catalina Island]] in the [[Pacific Ocean]]. Some of the most picturesque stands are found in [[Sonoma Valley]], Round Valley in [[Mendocino County]] and the southern [[Salinas Valley]] near the up-river reaches of the [[Salinas River (California)|Salinas River]].<ref name=h/><ref name=j/>

==Taxonomy==
Valley oak is of the [[white oak]] [[evolution]]ary lineage, which is officially known as the [[subgenus]] ''Lepidobalanus''. This subgenus comprises numerous oaks from California and elsewhere, which species share similar leaves, acorns, bark and [[wood pulp]]. Early [[History of California before 1900|settlers]] used a variety of common names for the valley oak including: white oak, bottom oak, swamp oak, water oak and mush oak. The [[Spaniard]]s, because the tree looked like the white oaks in Europe, called the tree "roble".

[[Image:Quercus lobata leaves Caswell Memorial State Park San Joaquin Valley California.jpg|thumb|right|220px|Leaves of ''Quercus lobata'']]

==Historical accounts==
In 1792, the English explorer [[George Vancouver]] noted on his expedition through the [[Santa Clara Valley]], after seeing an expanse of valley oaks: "For about twenty miles it could only be compared to a park which had originally been closely planted with the true old English oak; the underwood, that had probably attended its early growth, had the appearance of having been cleared away and left the stately lords of the forest in complete possession of the soil which was covered with luxuriant foliage."<ref name=z>Balls, E. K. (1972). ''Early Uses of California Plants'', University of California Press, Berkeley</ref>

In the year 1861, [[William Henry Brewer]], the chief [[botanist]] for the first [[California Geological Survey]] wrote of the valley oaks that he saw in [[Monterey County]]: "First I passed through a wild canyon, then over hills covered with oats, with here and there trees--oaks and pines. Some of these oaks were noble ones indeed. How I wish one stood in our yard at home....I measured one [valley oak] with wide spreading and cragged branches, that was 26.5 feet in circumference.  Another had a diameter of over six feet, and the branches spread over 75 feet each way. I lay beneath its shade a little while before going on."<ref name=z/>

The [[Hooker Oak]] of [[Chico, California]], was once considered the largest known valley oak. When it fell on May 1, 1977, it was nearly a hundred feet tall (30 m) and 29 feet (8.8 m) in circumference eight feet (2.4 m) from the ground.

==Uses==

===Commercial wood interest===
Difficulties in acquiring valley oak wood as well as issues stemming from its drying such as cracking and warping have shifted its consumption from a general purpose lumber to a primarily niche product.<ref name=USDA/> Valley oak wood has a small, but significant market for use in cabinetry though, and is also suitable for hardwood flooring.<ref name=USDA/> [[Tylose]]s present in the pores of valley oak wood increases its impermeability to fluids allowing it to be used in the production of water-tight vessels.<ref name=USDA/> Such vessels include wine barrels where valley oak wood sees limited role in the composition of and where it has similar properties to other [[List of Quercus species#Section Quercus|white oaks]] such as a reduced tannin load compared to the [[List of Quercus species#Section Lobatae|red oaks]] and an open grain that allows for an increased transfer of oxygen.<ref name=USDA/>

| image =

'''Quercus oblongifolia''', commonly known as the '''Arizona blue oak''', '''Blue live oak''' ,'''Sonoran blue oak''' , is an [[evergreen]] small tree or large shrub in the [[List of Quercus species#Section Quercus|white oak group]].

==Distribution==
''Quercus oblongifolia'' grows in high [[grassland]]s, [[canyon]]s and [[mesa]]s in [[Texas]], [[Arizona]] and [[New Mexico]] and northwestern Mexico ([[Baja California Sur]], [[Chihuahua (state)|Chihuahua]], [[Coahuila]], [[Sinaloa]] and [[Sonora]] in [[Mexico]].<ref name=FNA>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=233501068 Flora of North America, ''Quercus oblongifolia'']</ref><ref>[http://bonap.net/MapGallery/County/Quercus%20oblongifolia.png Biota of North America Program 2014 county distribution map]</ref><ref>[http://swbiodiversity.org/seinet/taxa/index.php?taxon=3243 SEINet, Southwestern Biodiversity, Arizona chapter]</ref>

==Description==
The Arizona blue oak is a small evergreen tree growing 5-8 meters (16-27 feet) tall with a rounded crown. At higher elevations it is typically a large shrub. The trunk is up to 50 cm (20 inches) in diameter and  the bark is light gray and densely furrowed. The twigs are yellowish brown and hairless with reddish brown buds. The leaves are small, alternate and oblong, with entire margins, leathery, bluish-green above and mid green below. The flowers appear in spring at the same time as the old leaves are being shed and new leaf growth starts. The male flowers form yellowish-green catkins and the female flowers are solitary or paired and grow in the leaf axils. The light brown acorns are ovoid or oblong, about 2 cm (0.8 inch) long and lodged in scaly, bowl-shaped cups about one third the length of the nut.<ref name=FNA/><ref>[http://www.dendro.cnre.vt.edu/dendrology/syllabus2/factsheet.cfm?ID=627 Virginia Tech: Mexican blue oak] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110509061003/http://www.dendro.cnre.vt.edu/dendrology/syllabus2/factsheet.cfm?ID=627 |date=May 9, 2011 }}</ref>

==Habitat==
This oak is common at elevations of 1200 to 1800 meters (4000-6000 feet). It is often found on thin sandy soils in semi-arid regions and is the dominant species in lower open oak woodland where it grows in association with Arizona white oak (''[[Quercus arizonica]]'') and Emory oak (''[[Quercus emoryi]]'').<ref name=Fire>[http://www.fs.fed.us/database/feis/plants/tree/queobl/all.html United States Department of Agriculture, National Forest Service, Fire Ecology]</ref> It is an important constituent of [[Pinyon-juniper woodland|pinyon-juniper]] communities.<ref>Pieper, Rex D.; Wood, M. Karl; Buchanan, Bruce B. 1988. Pinyon-juniper woodlands of New Mexico: a biological and economic appraisal. Special Report 73. Las Cruces, NM: New Mexico State University, College of Agriculture and Home Economics: 1-11.[5258]</ref> where it grows in association with species of [[Pinus|pine]] and [[Juniperus|juniper]], Arizona rosewood (''[[Vauquelinia californica]]''), shrubby buckwheat (''[[Eriogonum wrightii]]''), catclaw mimosa (''[[Mimosa aculeaticarpa]]''), bullgrass (''[[Muhlenbergia emersleyi]]''), plains lovegrass (''[[Eragrostis intermedia]]''), fendlerbush (''[[Fendlera|Fendlera rupicola]]'') and wolftail (''[[Lycurus phleoides]]'').<ref name=Fire/>

{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|regnum = [[Plant]]ae
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]

|binomial = ''Quercus palmeri''
|binomial_authority = [[George Engelmann|Engelm.]] 1880
|range_map = Quercus palmeri range map 1.png
|range_map_caption = Natural range of ''Quercus palmeri''
|synonyms_ref=<ref>[http://www.theplantlist.org/tpl1.1/record/kew-174238 The Plant List, ''Quercus palmeri'' Engelm. ]</ref>
|synonyms=*''Quercus chrysolepis'' var. ''palmeri'' <small>(Engelm.) Engelm.</small>
*''Quercus dunnii'' <small>Kellogg ex Curran</small>
|}}
'''''Quercus palmeri''''' is a species of [[oak]] known by the common name '''Palmer oak''', or '''Palmer's oak'''. It is native to [[California]], [[Baja California]], [[New Mexico]], and in [[Arizona]] through the [[Arizona transition zone|transition zone]] to the eastern [[Mogollon Rim]], where it grows in canyons, mountain slopes, washes, and other dry habitat types.<ref>[http://bonap.net/MapGallery/County/Quercus%20palmeri.png Biota of North America Program 2014 county distribution map]</ref><ref name=fna/><ref>[http://swbiodiversity.org/seinet/taxa/index.php?taxon=3591&taxauthid=1 SEINet, Southwestern Biodiversity, Arizona chapter]</ref>

==Description==
''Quercus palmeri'' is a [[shrub]] or small tree growing up to 3 meters (10 feet) tall, but known to reach 6 meters (20 feet) at times. It branches into angular twigs and is reddish brown. The leaves are 1 to 3 centimeters  (0.4-1.2 inches) in length. They are stiff, leathery, and brittle, their edges wavy with sharp spine-teeth. The upper surface is shiny, waxy, and olive green in color, the lower gray-green and coated with glandular hairs. The fruit is an [[acorn]] with a hairy cap up to 2.5 centimeters (1 inch) wide and a blunt-ended nut 2 to 3 centimeters (0.8-1.2 inches) long.<ref name=fna/>

''Quercus palmeri'' usually grows in small populations, some of which are actually [[Cloning|cloned]] growths of a single plant.<ref name=fna>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=233501072 Flora of North America, ''Quercus palmeri'']; [http://www.efloras.org/object_page.aspx?object_id=6856&flora_id=1 RangeMap]</ref> One such clone in the [[Jurupa Mountains]] in [[Riverside County, California]], named the [[Jurupa Oak]], was determined to be over 13,000 years old, a single individual living as a [[relict]] from the [[Pleistocene]].<ref>May, M. R., et al. (2009). [http://www.plosone.org/article/info%3Adoi%2F10.1371%2Fjournal.pone.0008346 Pleistocene clone of ''Quercus palmeri'' Engelm.] ''PLoS ONE''</ref> It is therefore one of the [[List of oldest trees|oldest living plants in the world]].

*''Quercus undulata'' var. ''wrightii'' <small>Engelm.</small>

'''''Quercus pungens''''', commonly known as the '''sandpaper oak''' or '''scrub oak''', is a North American species  [[evergreen]] or sub-evergreen shrub or small tree in the [[List of Quercus species#Section Quercus|white oak group]]. There is one recognised variety, ''Quercus pungens var. vaseyana'', the '''Vasey shin oak'''.<ref name=USDA>[http://www.fs.fed.us/database/feis/plants/tree/quepun/all.html USDA Forest Service: Quercus pungens]</ref> Sandpaper oak hybridizes with gray oak, ''[[Quercus grisea]]'', in the Guadalupe Mountains of New Mexico and Texas.<ref>Gehlbach, Frederick R. 1967. Vegetation of the Guadalupe Escarpment, New Mexico-Texas. Ecology. 48(3): 404-419.</ref>

==Distribution==
Sandpaper and Vasey shin oaks are abundant in the [[Edwards Plateau]] and the [[Trans-Pecos]] region of [[Texas]]. They also occur in the [[Guadalupe Mountains]] and westward to the mountains of southeastern [[Arizona]] and southwestern [[New Mexico]], and in northern and eastern Mexico ([[Chihuahua (state)|Chihuahua]], [[Coahuila]], [[Durango]], [[Nuevo León]], and [[Veracruz]]).<ref name=USDA/><ref>[http://bonap.net/MapGallery/County/Quercus%20pungens.png Biota of North America Program 2014 county distribution map]</ref><ref>[http://swbiodiversity.org/seinet/taxa/index.php?taxon=3246&taxauthid=1 SEINet, Southwestern Biodiversity, Arizona chapter]</ref>

==Description==
The sandpaper oak can be a small tree of up to 40 feet (12 meters) high or a large shrub that forms thickets. The bark is light brown and papery. The twigs are gray, with short velvety hairs, becoming smooth with age. The buds are dark red-brown, sparsely covered with hairs. The leathery leaves are semi-evergreen, being bright glossy green at first but turning darker with age. It is their rough texture, caused by minute persistent hair bases, that gives the tree its name of sandpaper oak. The [[inflorescence]], which appears in spring, is reddish, the female catkins having one to three flowers and the male catkins numerous flowers. The acorn cups are shallow and covered with dense gray hairs. The acorns grow singly or in pairs and are light brown, broadly ovoid with a rounded apex.<ref name=USDA/><ref name=FNA>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=233501077 Flora of North America]</ref>

==Habitat==
The preferred habitat of these oaks is on dry limestone or igneous slopes at a height of 800-2000 meters (2660-6670 feet) above sea level, in [[chaparral]] and desert scrub [[savanna]], usually in communities of [[oak]], [[juniper]] and [[pinyon pine]].<ref name=USDA/> In the chaparral formations in the Guadalupe Mountains, it is one of the dominant species and is found growing alongside true mountain-mahogany, ''[[Cercocarpus montanus]]'' and desert ceanothus, ''[[Ceanothus greggii]]''. Other plants associated with it include the Mohr shin oak, ''[[Quercus mohriana]]'', oneseed juniper, ''[[Juniperus monosperma]]'', cane cholla, ''[[Opuntia imbricata]]'', purplefruited pricklypear, ''[[Opuntia phaeacantha]]'', Mexican buckeye, ''[[Ungnadia speciosa]]'', Texas persimmon, ''[[Diospyros texana]]'', hairy tridens, ''[[Erioneuron pilosum]]'' and plateau oak, ''[[Quercus fusiformis]]''.<ref>Texas Parks and Wildlife Department. 1992. Plant communities of Texas (Series level): February 1992. Austin, TX: Texas Parks and Wildlife Department, Texas Natural Heritage Program. 38 p.</ref>

'''''Quercus rugosa''''', commonly known as the '''netleaf oak''', is a [[broad-leaved tree]] in the [[beech]] and [[oak]] family [[Fagaceae]]. It is [[native plant|native]] to southern [[North America]].

==Name==
''Quercus rugosa'' is [[Latin]] for "wrinkled oak". In [[Spanish language|Spanish]] it has many common names like "encino negro" (black oak) or "encino quiebra hacha" (axe-breaking oak).

==Description==
''Quercus rugosa'' is an [[evergreen]] shrub or tree.<ref name="CONABIO">[http://www.conabio.gob.mx/conocimiento/info_especies/arboles/doctos/31-fagac10m.pdf CONABIO'', Quercus rugosa'']</ref> Bark is brown and scaly.  Leaves are thick and leathery, rarely flat, usually cupped, up to 15 cm (6 inches) long, dark green on the top but covered with a thick of reddish-brown hairs on the underside.<ref name="efloras">[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=233501080 Flora of North America'', Quercus rugosa'' Née, 1801.  Netleaf oak ]</ref><ref name="BDL">[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/8009577#page/276/mode/1up Née, Luis. 1801.  Anales de Ciencias Naturales 3(9): 275] short diagnosis in Latin, description and commentary in Spanish</ref> Young leaves are also very hairy and usually red or yellow.
[[File:Quercus rugosa (detail).jpg|thumb|Leaves and acorns]]

==Distribution==
It is widespread in [[Mexico]], [[Guatemala]] and the southwestern [[United States]] ([[Arizona]], [[New Mexico]], western [[Texas]]).<ref name="PLANT" /><ref>[http://bonap.net/MapGallery/County/Quercus%20rugosa.png Biota of North America Program 2014 county distribution map]</ref><ref>[http://swbiodiversity.org/seinet/taxa/index.php?taxon=3264&taxauthid=1 SEINet, Southwestern Biodiversity, arizona chapter]</ref><ref>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/46657#page/3/mode/1up McVaugh, Rogers. 1974. Flora Novo-Galiciana: Fagaceae. Contributions from the University of Michigan Herbarium 12(1,3): 1–93. ]</ref><ref>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/87374#page/565/mode/1up Romero Rangel, S., E. C. Rojas Zenteno & M. L. Aguilar Enríquez. 2002. El género ''Quercus'' (Fagaceae) en el estado de México. Annals of the Missouri Botanical Garden  89(4): 551–593]</ref> It grows extensively in the [[Mexican Plateau|temperate highlands of central Mexico]], particularly on hillsides and in [[gully|narrow gorges]]. It is associated and usually coexists with other oaks, [[alder]]s, [[pine]]s and [[Arbutus xalapensis|Texas madrones]].

==See also==

* [[Madrean pine-oak woodlands]]
* [[Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt pine-oak forests]]

[[Image:Quercustomentella2.JPG|thumb|right|Foliage]]
'''''Quercus tomentella''''', the '''island oak''',<ref name=jeps>[http://ucjeps.berkeley.edu/cgi-bin/get_IJM.pl?tid=40764 ''Quercus tomentella''.] The Jepson Manual.</ref> '''island live oak''',<ref name=usda>[http://plants.usda.gov/core/profile?symbol=QUTO ''Quercus tomentella''.] USDA PLANTS.</ref> or '''Channel Island oak''',<ref name=fna>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=233501090 ''Quercus tomentella''.] Flora of North America.</ref> is an [[oak]] in the section [[List of Quercus species#Section Protobalanus|''Protobalanus'']]. It is native to six islands off the coast of [[California]] and to one Mexican island: five of the [[Channel Islands of California]] plus [[Guadalupe Island]] (part of the State of [[Baja California]]).<ref name=cnps>[http://www.rareplants.cnps.org/detail/1760.html ''Quercus tomentella''.] California Native Plant Society. Inventory of Rare and Endangered Plants. 2013.</ref>

==Description==
Island oak is a [[tree]] growing up to {{convert|20|m|ft}} in height.<ref name=fna/> The mature tree has a grayish to reddish brown trunk with scaly, furrowed [[bark]].<ref name=jeps/> The twigs are reddish and covered in woolly hairs. The leathery leaf blades are often concave and are an oblong lance shape or oval with pointed or rounded tips. The edges are smooth or toothed.<ref name=fna/> The upper surfaces are dark green and lightly hairy when new, losing the hairs over time. The undersides are gray-green and coated in woolly hairs, becoming less woolly with age.<ref name=jeps/> They are usually 7 to 10 centimeters (2.8-4.0 inches) long, sometimes up to 12 cm (4.8 inches). The [[acorn]] grows singly or in pairs. The cup has thick scales and woolly hairs and is up to 3 centimeters (1.2 inches) wide. The nut is up to 3.5 centimeters (1.4 inches) with a rounded tip.<ref name=jeps/><ref name=fna/>
==Biology==
Island oak [[Hybrid (biology)|hybridizes]] with [[Quercus chrysolepis|canyon live oak]] (''Quercus chrysolepis'').<ref name=fna/>

This species is a [[Relict (biology)|relict]]. Though it is now limited to the islands, it was once widespread in mainland California, as evidenced by the many [[Tertiary|late Tertiary]] [[fossil]]s of the species found there.<ref name=fna/>

==Conservation==
The island oak was listed as a [[vulnerable species]] by the [[International Union for Conservation of Nature]] in 1998.<ref name=iucn>Nixon, K., et al. 1998. [http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/30959/0 ''Quercus tomentella''.] In: IUCN 2013. IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Version 2013.1. Downloaded on 01 August 2013.</ref> Its [[NatureServe conservation status]] is also vulnerable.<ref name=ns>[http://www.natureserve.org/explorer/servlet/NatureServe?searchName=Quercus+tomentella ''Quercus tomentella''.] NatureServe. 2012.</ref>

The species is threatened by [[overgrazing]]. The most rapid declines have occurred on Guadalupe Island.<ref name=iucn/> The trees there are apparently no longer reproducing.<ref name=dela>de la Luz, J. L. L., et al. (2003). [http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/klu/bioc/2003/00000012/00000005/05094501 On the urgency of conservation on Guadalupe Island, Mexico: is it a lost paradise?] ''Biodiversity and Conservation'' 12(5), 1073-82.</ref> [[Feral goat]]s have been abundant on the island for at least 150 years. The animals have eliminated much of the native vegetation and caused extensive soil [[erosion]]. Fenced enclosures have been helpful in the early recovery of some of the local flora.<ref>Junak, S., et al. (2003). [http://www2.inecc.gob.mx/publicaciones/libros/477/cap6.html Esfuerzos recientes de conservación y apuntes sobre el estado actual de la flora de Isla Guadalupe, Baja California, México.] (Spanish) Presentation at ''Taller sobre la Restauración y Conservación de Isla Guadalupe'' [Workshop on Restoration and Conservation of Guadalupe Island]. Instituto Nacional de Ecología, November 13-14, 2003. [http://www.ine.gob.mx/ueajei/publicaciones/libros/477/abstracts.html HTML abstract] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070819075824/http://www.ine.gob.mx/ueajei/publicaciones/libros/477/abstracts.html |date=August 19, 2007 }} (English)</ref>

{{taxobox
 | image               = Quercus turbinella 3.jpg
 | image2              = Quercus turbinella 2.jpg
 | regnum              = [[Plant]]ae

 | species             = '''''Q. turbinella'''''
 | binomial            = ''Quercus turbinella''
 | binomial_authority  = [[Edward Lee Greene|Greene]] 1889
 | range_map           = Quercus turbinella range map 1.png
 | range_map_caption   = Natural range
 | synonyms_ref        = <ref>[http://www.theplantlist.org/tpl1.1/record/kew-175590 The Plant List, ''Quercus turbinella'' Greene ]</ref>
 | synonyms            = *''Quercus dumosa'' subsp. ''turbinella'' <small>(Greene) A.E.Murray 	</small>
*''Quercus dumosa'' var. ''turbinella'' <small>(Greene) Jeps.</small>
*''Quercus subturbinella'' <small>Trel.</small>
}}

'''''Quercus turbinella''''' is a North American species of [[oak]] known by the common names '''Turbinella oak''', '''Arizona shrub live oak''', and '''Gray shrub oak'''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://calphotos.berkeley.edu/cgi/img_query?where-genre=Plant&where-taxon=Quercus+turbinella|title=Calphotos photo gallery University of California}}</ref> It is native to northwestern [[Mexico]] and the southwestern United States<ref name=chiquito>Little. ''Atlas of United States Trees, Volume 3, Minor Western Hardwoods'', Map 147, ''Quercus turbinella''.</ref>

==Distribution==
''Quercus turbinella'' has been found in [[Baja California]], [[Sonora]], [[Arizona]], [[New Mexico]], [[Colorado]], [[Utah]], [[Nevada]], southern [[California]], and western [[Texas]].<ref>[http://bonap.net/MapGallery/County/Quercus%20turbinella.png Biota of North America Propgram 2014 county distribution map]</ref><ref>[http://www.calflora.org/cgi-bin/species_query.cgi?where-calrecnum=7008 Calflora taxon report, University of California, ''Quercus turbinella''  E. Greene, Grey oak, Sonoran scrub oak, shrub live oak ]</ref> It has to date not been found in [[Chihuahua (state)|Chihuahua]], but some of the known populations in Sonora and New Mexico lie only a few kilometers from the Chihuahuan border, so it is to be looked for in that state.<ref>[http://swbiodiversity.org/seinet/taxa/index.php?taxon=3272&taxauthid=1 SEINet, Southwestern Biodiversity, Arizona chapter] photos, description, interactive distribution map</ref> It grows in woodland, [[chaparral]], forest, and other habitat. It is most common in chaparral habitat in central [[Arizona]],<ref name=fs>[http://www.fs.fed.us/database/feis/plants/tree/quetur/all.html US Forest Service Fire Ecology]</ref> through the [[Arizona transition zone|transition zone]] of the [[Mogollon Rim]]–[[White Mountains (Arizona)|White Mountains]], but also southeast Arizona in the [[Madrean Sky Islands|Madrean Sky Island]] mountain ranges of [[sky island]]s.<ref name=chiquito/>

==Description== 
''Quercus turbinella'' is a [[shrub]] growing {{convert|2|-|5|m|ft|sp=us}} in height but sometimes becoming treelike and exceeding {{convert|6|m|ft|abbr=off|sp=us}}. The branches are gray or brown, the twigs often coated in short woolly fibers when young and becoming scaly with age. The thick, leathery evergreen leaves are up to {{convert|3|cm|in|abbr=off|sp=us}} long by {{convert|2|cm|in|abbr=on}} wide  and are edged with large, spine-tipped teeth. They are gray-green to yellowish in color and waxy in texture on the upper surfaces, and yellowish and hairy or woolly and glandular on the lower surfaces. The males catkins are yellowish-green and the female flowers are in short spikes in the leaf axils, appearing at the same time as the new growth of leaves. The fruit is a yellowish brown [[acorn]] up to two centimeters long with a shallow warty cup about a centimeter wide.<ref>[http://www.dendro.cnre.vt.edu/dendrology/syllabus2/factsheet.cfm?ID=629 Virginia Tech: Shrub live oak] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110509061012/http://www.dendro.cnre.vt.edu/dendrology/syllabus2/factsheet.cfm?ID=629 |date=May 9, 2011 }}</ref> This oak reproduces [[sexual reproduction|sexually]] via its acorns if there is enough moisture present, but more often it reproduces [[vegetative reproduction|vegetatively]] by sprouting from its [[rhizome]] and root crown.<ref name=fs/><ref>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=233501092 Flora of North America, ''Quercus turbinella'' Greene, 1889. Sonoran scrub oak ]</ref>

''Quercus turbinella'' easily [[Hybrid (biology)|hybridizes]] with other oak species, including ''[[Quercus gambelii]]'' and ''[[Quercus grisea|Q. grisea]]''.<ref name=fs/> Many species of animals use it for food, with wild and domesticated [[ungulate]]s browsing the foliage and many birds and mammals eating the acorns.<ref name=fs/> Animals also use the shrub as cover, and [[Cougar|mountain lions]] hide their kills in the thickets.<ref name=fs/>

(''Quercus macdonaldii'') |status = VU |status_system = IUCN2.3 |regnum = [[Plant]]ae |unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]] |unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]] |unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]] |ordo = [[Fagales]] |familia = [[Fagaceae]] |genus = ''[[Quercus]]'' |species = '''''Q.'' × ''macdonaldii''''' |binomial =''Quercus'' × ''macdonaldii'' |binomial_authority = Greene & Kellogg (pro sp.) [http://www.itis.gov/servlet/SingleRpt/SingleRpt?search_topic=TSN&search_value=19372 ITIS Standard Report Page: Quercus X macdonaldii] . accessed 2.28.2015 |synonyms = ''Quercus macdonaldii'' − [[Edward Lee Greene|Greene]]
''Quercus dumosa'' var. ''macdonaldii'' − (Greene & Kellogg) Jeps. |}} [[File:Quercus macdonaldii range map 1.png|thumb|310px|Distribution map for ''Quercus'' × ''macdonaldii'',
on the California [[Channel Islands of California|Channel Islands]].]] '''''Quercus'' × ''macdonaldii''''',[http://ucjeps.berkeley.edu/cgi-bin/get_IJM.pl?tid=76906 Jepson: ''Quercus'' × ''macdonaldii''] . accessed 2.28.2015[http://plants.usda.gov/core/profile?symbol=QUMA4 USDA: ''Quercus'' × ''macdonaldii''] . accessed 2.28.2015 formerly '''''Quercus macdonaldii''''', with the common names '''MacDonald's oak''' and '''Macdonald oak''', is a rare species of [[oak]] in the [[Fagaceae]] family. ==Distribution== The tree is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the California [[Channel Islands of California|Channel Islands]], on [[Santa Cruz Island]], [[Santa Rosa Island, California|Santa Rosa Island]], and [[Santa Catalina Island, California|Santa Catalina Island]], in [[Southern California]]. It is found in [[California chaparral and woodlands|chaparral and woodlands]] [[habitat]]s in canyons and slopes below {{convert|600|m|ft}}. ''Quercus'' × ''macdonaldii'' is a [[Vulnerable species]], threatened by [[habitat loss]].[http://www.iucnredlist.org/search/details.php/34008/all IUCN Red List: ''Quercus macdonaldii'']; Nixon, K. ''et al.'' 1998. ==Taxonomy== The plant was reclassified as '''''Quercus'' × ''macdonaldii''''', a naturally occurring hybrid of ''[[Quercus berberidifolia]]'' and ''[[Quercus lobata]]''. ==See also== *[[California chaparral and woodlands]] ecoregion :*[[California coastal sage and chaparral ecoregion|California coastal sage and chaparral sub-ecoregion]] *{{C|Natural history of the Channel Islands of California}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://ucjeps.berkeley.edu/cgi-bin/get_IJM.pl?tid=76906 Jepson eFlora treatment of ''Quercus'' × ''macdonaldii''] * [http://plants.usda.gov/core/profile?symbol=QUMA4 USDA Plants Profile for ''Quercus'' × ''macdonaldii'' [berberidifolia × lobata] (MacDonald oak)] * [http://www.calflora.org/cgi-bin/species_query.cgi?where-calrecnum=6982 Calflora Database: ''Quercus × macdonaldii'' (MacDonald's oak, MacDonald oak)] {{commons category|position=left}} {{Clear}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Quercus x macdonaldii}} [[Category:Quercus|macdonaldii]] [[Category:Endemic flora of California]] [[Category:Natural history of the Channel Islands of California]] [[Category:Natural history of the California chaparral and woodlands]] [[Category:Natural history of Los Angeles County, California]] [[Category:Trees of the Southwestern United States]] [[Category:Hybrid plants]] [[Category:Vulnerable flora of California]] {{Fagales-stub}}

{{italic title}} {{Taxobox | name = ''Rhus microphylla''
Littleleaf sumac | image = Rhus microphylla fruta.jpg | image_caption = ''Rhus microphylla'' fruit |regnum = [[Plantae]] |unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]] |unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]] |unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]] |ordo = [[Sapindales]] |familia = [[Anacardiaceae]] | genus = ''[[Rhus]]'' | species = '''''R. microphylla''''' | binomial = ''Rhus microphylla'' | binomial_authority = [[George Engelmann|Engelm.]]{{cite web |url=http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/taxon.pl?25621 |title=''Rhus microphylla'' Englm. |work= |publisher=United States Department of Agriculture |date= |accessdate=2010-05-13}} }} '''''Rhus microphylla''''', the '''littleleaf sumac''',{{PLANTS|id=RHMI3|taxon=Rhus microphylla|accessdate=21 October 2015}} '''desert sumac''', '''''correosa''''', or '''''agritos''''', is a species of [[sumac]] in the family [[Anacardiaceae]], native to [[North America]], in the [[southwestern United States]] and northern and central [[Mexico]], from central and western [[Texas]], southern [[New Mexico]], central and northern regions of the [[Mexican Altiplano]]-(Mexican Plateau), and extreme southeastern [[Arizona]] of the [[Madrean Sky Islands]]. ==References== {{reflist}} *Little. ''Atlas of United States Trees, Volume 3, Minor Western Hardwoods'', Little, Elbert L, 1976, US Government Printing Office. Library of Congress No. 79-653298. Map 159, ''Rhus microphyll''.  | species             = '''''R. ovata'''''
 | binomial            = ''Rhus ovata''
 | binomial_authority  = [[Sereno Watson|S.Watson]]
 | range_map           = Rhus ovata range map.png
 | range_map_caption   = Natural range
}}
'''''Rhus ovata''''', also known as '''sugar sumac'''<ref>{{PLANTS|id=RHOV|taxon=Rhus ovata|accessdate=21 October 2015}}</ref> or '''sugar bush''', is an evergreen [[shrub]] to small [[tree]] that grows in [[chaparral]] in dry [[canyons]] and south-facing slopes below 1300 m in [[Southern California]], [[Arizona]] and [[Baja California]].

==Distribution==
The main ''Rhus ovata'' population range is from the central and [[Pacific Ocean|Pacific]] region Baja California north into Pacific coastal [[Southern California]], and also in the central Arizona region of the [[Mogollon Rim]]. ''Rhus ovata'' often hybridizes with ''[[Rhus integrifolia]]''.

==Description==
''Rhus ovata'' size ranges from {{convert|2|–|10|m|ft|abbr=on}}, tall and it has a rounded appearance. The twigs are thick and reddish in color. Its foliage consists of dark green, leathery, ovate leaves that are folded along the [[midrib]]. The leaf arrangement is alternate.

Its [[inflorescences]] which occur at the ends of branches consist of small, 5-petaled, flowers that appear to be pink, but upon closer examination actually have white to pink [[petals]] with red [[sepals]]. Additionally, the [[flowers]] may be either bisexual or pistillate. The fruit is a reddish, sticky [[drupe]], and is small, about 6 – 8 mm in [[diameter]].

==Ecology==
The fruit and flowers are also popular with birds and butterflies and the plant itself provides good [[Habitat (ecology)|habitat]] for birds.

==Uses==

===Cultivation===
''Rhus ovata'' prefers well-drained soil in a sunny location, with little water once established, being a very drought-tolerant plant. It does not respond to formal boxed pruning well; however, as needed for wildfire fuel reduction or rejuvenation, occasional autumnal cutting, down to above the base crown, is done for new basal sprouting.

===Fruit===
The fruit of ''Rhus ovata'' can be used to make a drink similar to [[lemonade]].

==See also==
*[[California chaparral and woodlands]] - (''ecoregion'')
*[[California coastal sage and chaparral ecoregion|California coastal sage and chaparral]]  - subecoregion
*[[Coastal sage scrub]] - (''plant association'')	
*[[California montane chaparral and woodlands]]  - subecoregion

133.text:
{{taxobox
|image = Robinia neomexicana1.jpg
|regnum = [[Plant]]ae
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]]
|ordo = [[Fabales]]
|familia = [[Fabaceae]]
|subfamilia = [[Faboideae]]
|tribus = [[Robinieae]]
|genus = ''[[Robinia]]''
|species = '''''R. neomexicana'''''
|binomial = ''Robinia neomexicana''
|binomial_authority = [[Asa Gray|A.Gray]]
|range_map =  Robinia neomexicana range map.jpg
|range_map_caption = Natural range
}}

'''''Robinia neomexicana''''', the '''New Mexican locust''', '''New Mexico, Southwest, Desert, Pink,''' or '''rose locust'''), is a [[shrub]] or small [[tree]] in the subfamily [[Faboideae]] of the pea family [[Fabaceae]].

==Distribution==
''R. neomexicana'' is native to the [[Southwestern United States]] (southeastern [[California]] and southwestern [[Utah]], [[Virgin River]] region,<ref>Little. ''Atlas of United States Trees, Volume 3, Minor Western Hardwoods'', Little, Elbert L, 1976, US Government Printing Office. Library of Congress No. 79-653298. Map 162, ''Robinia neomexicana''.</ref> east through [[Arizona]] and [[New Mexico]], the [[Rio Grande]] valley, to far west [[Texas]]) and adjoining northern [[Mexico]]; from central New Mexico the range extends north into [[Colorado]], mostly the eastern foothills of the [[Rocky Mountains]]. In Arizona, it ranges across the [[Arizona transition zone]], the [[Mogollon Rim]] and [[White Mountains (Arizona)|White Mountains]], and into western and southwestern New Mexico.<ref>Little. ''Atlas of United States Trees, Volume 3, Minor Western Hardwoods'', Map 162, ''Robinia neomexicana''.</ref>  

In [[California]], it is uncommon below 1500 m (5000 ft) in canyons in the [[Mojave Desert]] and its [[sky island]] [[Single-leaf Pinyon|pinyon]]-[[Juniperus californica|juniper]] [[habitat]]s (''[[Single-leaf Pinyon|Pinus monophylla]]'' and ''[[Juniperus californica]]'').<ref name=Jepson>{{cite web | title = Jepson Manual Treatment | year = 1993 | publisher = University of California | url = http://ucjeps.berkeley.edu/cgi-bin/get_JM_treatment.pl?3691,4198,4199 | accessdate = 2008-06-18}}</ref> Farther east, it is typically found between 1200 and 2600 meters (4000 and 8500 feet) along streams, in the bottoms of valleys, and on the sides of canyons.<ref name=Elmore>{{cite book | author=Elmore, Francis H. | title=Trees and Shrubs of the Southwest Uplands | publisher=Western National Parks Association | year=1976 | isbn = 0-911408-41-X | page = 134}}</ref>

==Description==
''R. neomexicana'' grows to 5–10 m tall (rarely to 15 m) with bristly shoots. The [[leaf|leaves]] are 10–15 cm long, pinnate with 7–15 leaflets; they have a pair of sharp, reddish-brown thorns at the base. The [[flower]]s are showy and white or pink, and considered fragrant. <ref>http://www.fireflyforest.com/flowers/category/fragrant-flowers-and-plants/</ref>  Blooms are produced in spring or early summer in dense [[raceme]]s 5–10 cm long that hang from the branches near the ends.<ref name=Jepson/><ref name=Elmore/>  The fruits are brown bean-like pods with bristles like those on the shoots.<ref name=Elmore/>

==Uses==
In New Mexico, [[Pueblo]] [[Native Americans in the United States|Native Americans]] traditionally ate the flowers uncooked.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/32501881|title=Wild plants of the Pueblo Province : exploring ancient and enduring uses|last=Dunmire|first=William W.|last2=Tierney|first2=Gail D.|date=1995|publisher=Museum of New Mexico Press|year=|isbn=0890132828|location=|pages=|oclc=32501881|quote=|via=}}</ref>

[[Mule deer]], cattle, and [[goat]]s browse the plant foliage. [[Squirrel]]s and [[quail]] eat the locust's seeds.<ref name=Elmore/>

==References==
{{reflist}}

==Further reading==
*Little. ''Atlas of United States Trees, Volume 3, Minor Western Hardwoods'', Little, Elbert L, 1976, US Government Printing Office. Library of Congress No. 79-653298. Map 162, ''Robinia neomexicana''.

{{taxobox

|species = '''''S. bonplandiana'''''
|binomial = ''Salix bonplandiana''
|binomial_authority = [[Carl Sigismund Kunth|(H.B.K.)-Kunth]]
|range_map = Salix bonplandiana range map 2.png
|range_map_caption = Natural range of ''Salix bonplandiana''
|}}

'''''Salix bonplandiana''''' ('''Bonpland willow'''), (Span.: ''ahuejote'', ''sauce'', ''ahujote'', and ''huejote''),<ref>[http://www.jornada.unam.mx/2003/09/29/eco-f.html City trees, (www.jornada.unam.mx);]</ref> is a [[perennial]] species of [[willow]] [[tree]] native to southern and southwest [[Mexico]] and extending into central [[Guatemala]];<ref>Little, ''Atlas of United States Trees, Volume 3, Minor Western Hardwoods'', Map 166-SW, Map 166-N ''Salix bonplandiana''.</ref> in western Mexico it is a tree of the [[Sierra Madre Occidental]] cordillera, but also occurring in other small locales, for example [[Baja California Sur]], northern [[Sonora]], [[San Luis Potosi]], etc. A core [[disjunct distribution|disjunct]] area occurs in central and southeast [[Arizona]], in advantageous locales, especially associated with higher elevations and water.<ref>Little, Map 166-SW, Map 166-N ''Salix bonplandiana''.</ref>

==Distribution==
In Mexico, the Bonpland willow is associated with the Pacific Coast, and in southern Mexico, the range extends into internal mountain areas of Pacific, central-southwest [[Guatemala]]. Across southern Mexico, it is a species of the [[Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt]],<ref>Little, Map 166-SW, Map 166-N ''Salix bonplandiana''.</ref>  and has its range extension on the Pacific, west from the west of the Volcanic Belt, and then north into the [[Sierra Madre Occidental]] cordillera. In the cordillera, the range ends in southwest [[Chihuahua (state)|Chihuahua]], but is disjunct in a large area of central [[Arizona]], the [[Mogollon Rim]]–[[White Mountains (Arizona)]] and extending into the [[Madrean Sky Islands]] southeastwards, including mountain-related isolated locales in the [[New Mexico Bootheel|bootheel of extreme southwest]] [[New Mexico]].<ref>Little, Map 166-SW, Map 166-N ''Salix bonplandiana''.</ref>

===Identical ranges of ''S. bonplandiana'', ''S. taxifolia''===
Both ''S. bonplandiana'', and ''[[Salix taxifolia|S. taxifolia]]'' have identical ranges; both species range from the Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt southward, on an imaginary centerline into central [[Guatemala]]. Each is on the Pacific Coast, but leave the [[wildlife corridor|coastal strip]] before the range extension into central Guatemala. Both have their [[disjunct distribution|disjunct]] ranges in Arizona, both being in the [[Madrean Sky Islands]] region. Both also range into [[Baja California Sur]], but ''S. taxifolia'' only at the extreme south.<ref>Little, Maps 166-N & 183-N; Maps 166-SW & 183-SW, ''S. bonplandiana'', ''S. taxifolia''.</ref> (''S. bonplandiana'' also occurs in Arizona, in the Mogollon Rim–White Mountains regions.)

The other differences between the two are ''S. taxofolia'' occurs in minor locales of the [[Sierra Madre Oriental]] cordillera, and ''S. bonplandiana'' occurs in the Sierra Madre Occidental cordillera northwest to southwest [[Durango]]. ''S. taxifolia'' occurs west of the Occidental cordillera in the south Pacific Coast north to southern [[Sinaloa]]–southwest Durango. ''B. bonplandiana'' has a few locales on the [[Mexican Plateau]], (with both occurring in central [[Chihuahua (state)|Chihuahua]], west of [[Chihuahua, Chihuahua]]).<ref>Little, Maps 166-N & 183-N; Maps 166-SW & 183-SW, ''S. bonplandiana'', ''S. taxifolia''.</ref> Other minor locale differences occur in central [[New Mexico]], far west [[Texas]], [[Coahuila]], [[Nuevo Leon]], and [[Tamaulipas]].

'''''Salix laevigata''''' ('''red willow''' or '''polished willow'''), is a species of [[willow]] native to the [[southwestern United States]]  and northern [[Baja California]].<ref name=Little>Little. ''Atlas of United States Trees, Volume 3, Minor Western Hardwoods'',  Map 176, ''Salix laevigata''.</ref>

==Biology==
The red willow is a small tree up to {{convert|45|ft|m|abbr=on}} in height. Like most other willows, it commonly grows along riverbanks and in other areas with high soil moisture.<ref>[http://ucjeps.berkeley.edu/cgi-bin/get_IJM.pl?tid=42850 The Jepson Manual.]</ref>

==Distribution==
The red willow occurs along the coast of Baja California and in California north to [[Cape Mendocino]]. It occurs east of the [[San Joaquin Valley]] in the lower elevation western foothills of the [[Sierra Nevada (U.S.)|Sierra Nevada]]; it is absent from the Central Valley itself.<ref name=Little/> Small occurrences can be found in [[Oregon]], [[Nevada]], and [[New Mexico]]. In [[Arizona]] it is found in the central [[Arizona transition zone|transition zone]] of the [[Mogollon Rim]] and in the central [[Grand Canyon]]. Its distribution extends to the [[Virgin River]] canyon of southwestern [[Utah]].<ref name=Little/>
==Ethnobotany==
The [[Kutenai language|Kutenai]] called red willow ''mukwuʔk'', and used it in basketry.<ref>{{Cite web
| title = FirstVoices: Ktunaxa words
| accessdate = 2012-07-10
| url = http://www.firstvoices.com/en/Ktunaxa/word/66bc5bf3920cac39/Red+Osier+-+Red+Willow
}}</ref>

==References==
{{reflist}}

==Further reading==

|synonyms_ref=<ref>[http://www.tropicos.org/Name/28300202?tab=synonyms Tropicos]</ref><ref>[http://www.theplantlist.org/tpl1.1/record/kew-5002113 The Plant List]</ref>
|}}

'''''Salix taxifolia''''' ('''yewleaf''' or '''yew-leaf willow''') is a species of [[willow]] native to all of southern [[Mexico]], also Pacific Coast regions, north to [[Sinaloa]], and in the south Pacific Coast of Mexico into central [[Guatemala]]. Scattered populations are also reported from northern Mexico and from the US states of Texas, New Mexico, and Arizona.<ref name=Little-183>Elbert L. Little (1976), ''Atlas of United States Trees, Volume 3, Minor Western Hardwoods'', US Government Printing Office. Library of Congress No. 79-653298, Map 183-SW, Map 183-N, ''Salix taxifolia''.</ref><ref>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=242445883 Flora of North America, vol 7 p 54].</ref><ref>Laferrière, Joseph E. 1994. Vegetation and flora of the Mountain Pima village of Nabogame, Chihuahua, Mexico. Phytologia 77:102-140.</ref>

It is a large [[shrub]] or [[tree]] with narrow linear leaves similar to those of a [[yew]] ([[Taxus]] spp.), thus its common name. Its range is similar to that of the Bonpland willow, ''[[Salix bonplandiana|S. bonplandiana]]''.

==Distribution==
The primary range of yewleaf willow is southern [[Mexico]] south of the [[Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt]] and the Pacific coast region, then into Pacific coast–central [[Guatemala]].<ref name=Little-183/>

Besides the core range area, (of the northern Sierra Madre Occidentals) in Arizona–New Mexico and northeast Sonora,<ref name=Little-183/> two larger [[disjunct distribution|disjunct]] regions occur in west [[Texas]] and central [[Chihuahua (state)|Chihuahua]].<ref name=Little-183/> South of [[Chihuahua, Chihuahua]] it is found at the [[Conchos River]], and west of the city, a large area at the lake region. It also occurs in scattered, isolated locales of [[Durango]], [[Sinaloa]], and in the northeast at [[Nuevo Leon]] and [[Tamaulipas]]: also extreme southern [[Baja California Sur]], (west of Sinaloa-Durango across the [[Gulf of California]]).<ref name=Little-183/> Besides parts of the Sierra Madre Occidental, locales occur in the southern [[Sierra Madre Oriental]] cordillera, but also small isolated locales as far northeast as the northeast states.

Its range is similar to that of the Bonpland willow, ''[[Salix bonplandiana]]'', except ''S. bonplandiana'' covers almost the entire north-south extent of the Sierra Madre Occidentals; yewleaf is more intermittent in that range.

===Similar ranges of ''S. taxifolia'', ''S. bonplandiana''===
Both ''S. taxifolia'', and ''[[Salix bonplandiana|S. bonpandiana]]'' have identical ranges: both species range from the [[Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt]] southward, on an imaginary centerline into central [[Guatemala]]. Each is on the Pacific Coast, but leave the [[wildlife corridor|coastal strip]] before the range into central Guatemala. Both have their [[disjunct distribution|disjunct]] ranges in Arizona, both being in the [[Madrean Sky Islands]] region. Both also range into [[Baja California Sur]], but ''S. taxifolia'' only at the extreme south.<ref Name=Little-166>Little (1976), Maps 166-N & 183-N; Maps 166-SW & 183-SW, ''S. bonplandiana'', ''S. taxifolia''.</ref> (''S. bonplandiana'' also occurs in Arizona, in the Mogollon Rim–White Mountains regions.)

The other differences between the two: ''S. taxofolia'' occurs in minor locales of the [[Sierra Madre Oriental]] cordillera, and ''S. bonplandiana'' occurs in the Sierra Madre Occidental cordillera northwest to southwest [[Durango]]. ''S. taxifolia'' occurs ''west'' of the Occidental cordillera in the south Pacific Coast north to southern [[Sinaloa]]–southwest Durango. ''B. bonplandiana'' has a few locales on the [[Mexican Plateau]], (with both occurring in central [[Chihuahua (state)|Chihuahua]], west of [[Chihuahua, Chihuahua]]).<ref name=Little-166/> Other minor locale differences occur in central [[New Mexico]], far west [[Texas]], [[Coahuila]], [[Nuevo Leon]], and [[Tamaulipas]].

137.text:
{{Italic title}} {{taxobox |name= ''Sapindus saponaria'' |image= Sapindus saponaria Blanco2.388-cropped.jpg | image_width = 300px | image_caption = ''Sapindus saponaria'', late 19th century botanical illustration |regnum = [[Plant]]ae |unranked_divisio = [[Flowering plant|Angiosperms]] |unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]] |unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]] |ordo = [[Sapindales]] |familia = [[Sapindaceae]] |genus = ''[[Sapindus]]'' |species = '''''S. saponaria''''' |binomial = ''Sapindus saponaria'' |binomial_authority = [[Carl Linnaeus|L.]]{{cite web |url=http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/taxon.pl?33090 |title=Taxon: ''Sapindus saponaria'' L. |work=Germplasm Resources Information Network |publisher=United States Department of Agriculture |date=1994-08-23 |accessdate=2010-11-02}} |subdivision_ranks = Subspecies |subdivision =S. s. var. ''drummondii''
''S. s.'' var. ''saponaria'' }} [[File:Starr 050407-6253 Sapindus saponaria.jpg|thumb|''Sapindus saponaria'']] '''''Sapindus saponaria''''' is a small to medium-sized [[deciduous]] [[tree]]{{cite book |author=Matt Turner |title=Remarkable Plants of Texas: Uncommon Accounts of Our Common Natives (Corrie Herring Hooks Series) |publisher=University of Texas Press |location=Austin |year=2009 |pages=95–97 |isbn=0-292-71851-9 |oclc= |doi= |accessdate=}} native to the [[Americas]]. Common names include '''wingleaf soapberry''',{{PLANTS|id=SASA4|taxon=Sapindus saponaria|accessdate=5 November 2015}} '''western soapberry''', '''jaboncillo''', '''sulluku'''Hugo E. Delgado Sumar, ''Los recursos curativos vegetales en la medicina tradicional peruana''Louis Girault, ''Kallawaya - guérisseurs itinérants des Andes. Recherches sur les pratiques médicinales et magiques.'' Paris 1984. p. 301. ''Cholokke, Sulluku (K). Sapindus saponaria''César del Solar Meza, Rainer Hostnig (2006): ''Litograbados indígenas en la arquitectura colonial del Departamento del Cusco, Perú'' and '''mānele''' ([[Hawaiian language|Hawaiian]]).{{cite web |url=http://www2.hawaii.edu/~eherring/hawnprop/sap-sapo.htm |title=''Sapindus saponaria'' |work=Hawaiian Native Plant Propagation Database |publisher=University of Hawaiʻi at Mānoa |accessdate=2010-11-02}} Its [[genus]] name, "''Sapindus''", comes from the [[Latin language|Latin]], meaning [[India]]n [[soap]], and its [[Specific name (botany)|specific epithet]] means "soapy." ==Description== It often grows in clumps or thickets reaching about 20 ft. (6.1 m) in height in the western part of its range. Solitary trees though can grow as tall as 50 ft. (15.2 m) in height. In the western part of its range it is most often found growing at the head of prairie ravines, the margins of woodlands, the edges of fields or on rocky hillsides. The leaves of the soapberry are alternate, pinnately compound, thick and leathery but deciduous, 8 in. (20 cm) to 15 in. (38 cm) in length, made up of 6 to 20 narrow lanceolate leaflets with smooth margins, long tapered tips, and uneven wedge-shaped bases which are 2 in. to 5 in. (5 cm to 13 cm) long and .75 in. to 1.5 in. (2 cm to  cm) wide. Midveins on leaves of var. ''saponaria'' are mostly winged, while those of var. ''drummondii'' are never winged. The inflorescence are dense terminal panicles of small white flowers 6 in. to 10 in (15 cm to 20 cm) long. Flowering occurs in May–June for var. ''drummondii'' and in November for var. ''saponaria''. The fruit occur in large pyramidal clusters at the ends of branches. Each golden colored fruit is between 1.2 in. to 1.4 in. (3 cm to 3.6 cm) in diameter and becomes translucent and wrinkled when fully mature and contains a single black seed about .35 in (9 mm) in diameter. Fruits of var. ''drummondii'' ripen in October and often remain on the tree until spring, while those of var. ''saponaria'' ripen in spring. The twigs of var. ''drummondii'' are gray-brown and hairy with short tan colored hairs while those of var. ''saponaria'' are gray and hairless. Buds on var. ''drummondii'' are small dark brown and hairy while those on var. ''saponaria'' are small brown and hairless. The trunk of var. ''drummondii'' has light gray, scaly with thin plate like bark and sometimes shallowly furrowed while var. ''saponaria'' has gray to reddish colored scaly bark. ==Subspecies== *S. s. var. ''drummondii'' ([[William Jackson Hooker|Hook.]] & [[George Arnott Walker-Arnott|Arn.]]) [[Lyman David Benson|L.D.Benson]] (syn. ''S. drummondii'' Hook. & Arn.) – Western soapberry{{ITIS |id=530240 |taxon=''Sapindus saponaria'' var. ''drummondii'' |accessdate=2010-11-02}} native from [[Arizona]] across to [[Louisiana]] in the south ranging north to [[Kansas]] and far southwestern [[Missouri]] in the north. It is also native to the states of [[Sonora]], [[Chihuahua (state)|Chihuahua]], and [[Coahuila]] in [[Mexico]]. *''S. s.'' var. ''saponaria'' (syn. ''S. marginatus'' [[Carl Ludwig Willdenow|Willd.]], ''S. thurstonii'' [[Joseph Rock|Rock]]) – Wingleaf soapberry{{ITIS |id=530241 |taxon=''Sapindus saponaria'' var. ''saponaria'' |accessdate=2010-11-02}} native almost exclusively to far south [[Florida]] in the [[United States]] but also occurs in an isolated area of coastal southeast [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]]. It is also found in the [[Caribbean]], [[Central America|Central]] and [[South America]], and [[Hawaii (island)|island of Hawai{{okina}}i]]. ==Notable specimens== *The US national champion ''Sapindus saponaria'' var. ''drummondii'' is located in southern [[Johnson County, Kansas]] and measures 59 ft. (18 m) tall, 39 ft. (11.9 m) wide with a trunk diameter at 4 1/2 ft. (1.4 m) of 10 1/2 ft. (3.2 m) in circumference.{{cite web |url=http://www.americanforests.org/bigtree/sapindus-saponaria-var-drummondii/ |title=Western Soapberry Record |author=American Forests |date=2007 |accessdate=June 29, 2012}} *The US national champion ''Sapindus saponaria'' var. ''saponaria'' is located in [[Hawaii County, Hawaii]] and measures 73 ft. (22.25 m) tall, 57 ft. (1.74 m) wide with a trunk diameter at 4 1/2 ft. (1.4 m) of 2 1/2 ft. (76 cm) in circumference.{{cite web |url=http://www.americanforests.org/bigtree/sapindus-saponaria-2/ |title=Wingleaf Soapberry Record |author=American Forests |date=2007 |accessdate=June 29, 2012}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commonscat-inline|Sapindus saponaria|''Sapindus saponaria''}} {{Wikispecies-inline|Sapindus saponaria|''Sapindus saponaria''}} [[Category:Sapindus|saponaria]] [[Category:Plants described in 1753]] [[Category:Trees of the North-Central United States]] [[Category:Trees of the Caribbean]] [[Category:Trees of Central America]] [[Category:Trees of Hawaii]] [[Category:Trees of Mexico]] [[Category:Trees of South America]] [[Category:Trees of the Southeastern United States]] [[Category:Trees of the Southwestern United States]] [[Category:Trees of Peru]] [[sw:Mmoyomoyo]]

138.text:
{{italic title}} {{taxobox |image = Acacia greggii thorns.jpg |status = G5 |status_system = TNC |regnum = [[Plant]]ae |unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]] |unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]] |unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]] |ordo = [[Fabales]] |familia = [[Fabaceae]] |genus = ''[[Senegalia]]'' |species = '''''S. greggii''''' |binomial = ''Senegalia greggii'' |binomial_authority = ([[Asa Gray|A.Gray]]) Britton & Rose |range_map = Acacia-greggii-range-map.png |range_map_caption = Global occurrence of ''S. greggii'' |range_map2 = Acacia greggii range map 1.png |range_map2_caption = ''S. greggii'' var. ''greggii'' natural range |range_map3 = Acacia wrightii range map 1.png |range_map3_caption = ''S. greggii'' var. ''wrightii'' natural range |subdivision_ranks = varieties |subdivision = *''Senegalia greggii'' var. ''arizonica'' Isely *''Senegalia greggii'' var. ''greggii'' (A. Gray) Britton & Rose |}} '''''Senegalia greggii''''' is a species of ''[[Senegalia]]'' native to the [[southwestern United States]] and northern [[Mexico]], from the extreme south of [[Utah]] (where, at 37°10' N it is the northernmost naturally occurring ''Senegalia'' species anywhere in the world{{citation needed|date=April 2013}}) south through southern [[Nevada]], southeast [[California]], [[Arizona]], [[New Mexico]] and western [[Texas]] to [[Baja California]], [[Sinaloa]] and [[Nuevo León]] in Mexico. Common names include '''catclaw acacia''', '''catclaw mesquite''', '''Gregg's catclaw''', '''paradise flower''', '''wait-a-minute bush''', and '''wait-a-bit tree'''; these names mostly come from the fact that the tree has numerous hooked '''prickles''' with the shape and size of a [[cat]]'s claw, that tend to hook onto passers-by; the hooked person must stop ("wait a minute") to remove the '''prickles''' carefully to avoid injury or shredded clothing. (Note: "cat's claw" is also used to refer to ''[[Uncaria tomentosa]]'', a woody vine found in the tropical jungles of South and Central America) The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] ''greggii'' refers to [[Josiah Gregg]], author, explorer, and amateur naturalist of the [[Southwestern United States|American Southwest]] and northern Mexico. ==Ecology== ''Senegalia greggii'' is most common in [[Arroyo (creek)|arroyos]] where its roots have access to deep water. Its seeds require physical [[Scarification (botany)|scarification]] in order to germinate. This effectively prevents [[germination]] unless a [[flash flood]] disturbs the area and deposits enough water to increase the likelihood that seedlings will be able to establish deep enough roots to survive the dry season. Catclaw is fully [[drought]] [[deciduous]] and will usually lack [[Leaf|leaves]] for most of the year. ''S. greggii'' has [[Extrafloral nectary|extrafloral nectaries]], a trait shared with other senegalias. A tentative connection has been made between these glands and [[insect]]s that would suggest a [[Mutualism (biology)|mutualistic]] relationship (as found in other ''Senegalia'' species). [[Ant]]s are known to use the glands as a source of food and water, and may provide some defense for the plant against [[Herbivore|herbivorous]] insects. Like other arroyo trees in family [[Fabaceae]], ''S. greggii'' is frequently afflicted with Desert Mistletoe, ''[[Phoradendron]] [[Phoradendron californicum|californicum]]''. Unlike other legumes, ''S. greggii'' is not known to form [[root nodule]] associations with [[Nitrogen fixation|nitrogen-fixing]] [[Diazotroph|bacteria]]. It is argued that this species may be an example of an evolutionary [[anachronism]], in which the range and renewal of the species is limited due to the [[Quaternary extinction event#The Pleistocene or Ice Age extinction event|extinction]] of the mammalian [[megafauna]] responsible for [[Endozoochory|seed dispersal]]. Within this model, the scarification required to germinate the seeds would have occurred during the chewing and [[digestion]] of the fruit by a large [[mammal]], who later passes the seed intact some distance from the original tree. ==Description== [[Image:Acacia greggii1.jpg|thumb|200px|
''Senegalia greggii''
]] It is a large [[shrub]] or small [[tree]] growing to {{convert|10|-|15|m|ft|abbr=on}} tall with a trunk up to {{convert|20|-|30|cm|in|abbr=on}} diameter. The grey-green [[leaf|leaves]] are [[deciduous]], and bipinnate, divided into 1-3 pairs of pinnae, each pinna {{convert|2|-|3|cm|abbr=on}} long with 10-18 [[leaflet (botany)|leaflets]] that are {{convert|3|-|6|mm|in|abbr=on}}. Pinnae are most frequently in two pairs, with the proximal pair perpendicular to the petiolule and the distal pair forming a V at the tip. The blooms are produced in dense cylindrical spikes of numerous flowers, each individual flower with five cream colored {{convert|3|mm|in|adj=on|abbr=on}} [[petal]]s and numerous creamy yellow {{convert|6|mm|in|adj=on|abbr=on}} [[stamen]]s. The [[fruit]] is a flat, twisted [[legume]] (pod) {{convert|6|-|15|cm|in|abbr=on}} long, containing generally 3 to 5 hard, flattened, medium brown [[seed]]s. The seed pod is constricted between seeds (a [[loment]]), and [[seed dispersal]] occurs both through [[Dehiscence (botany)|dehiscence]] and breaks at these constrictions. ==Ethnobotany== ''Senegalia greggii'', even though it is used as [[Fodder|forage]] for livestock, contains a potentially poisonous [[cyanogenic glycoside]] called [[prunasin]].[http://www.ivis.org/special_books/Knight/chap1/ivis.pdf Plants Causing Sudden Death by A. P. Knight and R. G. Walter] Mature seeds are to be avoided, as the native people did. ''S. greggii'' young, unripe beans were gathered and eaten by desert [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|tribes]] of [[North America]], including the [[Chemehuevi]] of the [[Southern Paiute]], the [[Pima people|Pima]], and the [[Cahuilla]]. The Cahuilla also ground the dried beans for mush and cakes, while the [[Havasupai]] ground it to make flour for bread. The [[Seri people|Seri]] ground the beans to meal then mixed it with water and sea lion oil for [[porridge]]. The [[Diegueno]] used ''S. greggii'' as food for domesticated animals. The Cahuilla and Pima used the fibers for sturdy construction material and firewood. The Havasupai split the twigs and used them for [[basketry]], but also used the twigs as a broom to brush off [[metate|metates]]. The O'odham (formerly called [[Tohono O'odham|Papago]]) used the broken twigs for baskets, and were curved to make intricate weaves in the baskets. The Pima used the dried bushes to pile them to make a brush fence. The branches were used to make cradle frames as well. The Tohono O'odham fitted the branches around deer hunters' heads to make a disguise, and the buds and blossoms were dried to make perfume sachets by the women. The sticks were also used to dislodge [[saguaro]] fruits from the [[cactus]] body, and rods were curved to flesh animal skins. The Akimel O'odham made bows out of the wood.{{cite web|title=Acacia greggii Gray|url=http://herb.umd.umich.edu/herb/search.pl|website=http://herb.umd.umich.edu/|accessdate=2015}} [[Image:Acacia-greggii-flower.jpg|thumb|200px|right|''Senegalia greggii'' Flower]] ==Some chemical compounds found in ''Senegalia greggii''== *[[Beta-methyl-phenethylamine]][http://uvalde.tamu.edu/pdf/chemtdaf.pdf Chemistry of Acacias from South Texas] *[[Catechin]] *[[Fisetin]] *[[Hordenine]] *[[Phenethylamine]] *[[Quercetin]] *[[Tyramine]] ==Gallery== Image:Acacia greggii branch.jpg|
''Senegalia greggii'' branch
Image:Acacia greggii seeds.jpg|
''Senegalia greggii'' seeds
Image:Acacia greggii2.jpg|
Catclaw Acacia thorn
Image:Acacia-greggii-bark.jpg|
Bark

Basic Books:NY. * [http://ucjeps.berkeley.edu/cgi-bin/get_JM_treatment.pl?3691,3692,3699 Jepson Manual Treatment: ''Senegalia greggii'' (as ''Acacia greggii'')] * [http://www.fs.fed.us/database/feis/plants/shrub/acagre/botanical_and_ecological_characteristics.html U.S. Forest Service FEIS Database: ''Senegalia greggii'' (as ''Acacia greggii'')] * Lawor, Elizabeth Jane (1995). ''Archaeological Site-formation Processes Affecting Plant Remains in the Mojave Desert.''. University of California, Riverside. * [http://www.asft.ttu.edu/cfire/databases/range3.html Range Shrubs] *[http://www.plantmaps.com/nrm/acacia-greggii-catclaw-acacia-native-range-map.php Interactive Distribution Map of ''Senegalia greggii'' (as ''Acacia greggii'')] ==External links== {{Commons category|Senegalia greggii|position=left}} {{Wikispecies|Acacia greggii|''Senegalia greggii''}} [[Category:Senegalia|greggii]] [[Category:North American desert flora]] [[Category:Flora of the Chihuahuan Desert]] [[Category:Flora of the Sonoran Deserts]] [[Category:Flora of the California desert regions]] [[Category:Flora of the U.S. Rio Grande Valleys]] [[Category:Trees of the Southwestern United States]] [[Category:Trees of Baja California]] [[Category:Trees of Chihuahua (state)]] [[Category:Trees of Coahuila]] [[Category:Trees of the South-Central United States]] [[Category:Trees of Nuevo León]] [[Category:Trees of Sinaloa]] [[Category:Trees of Sonora]] [[Category:Trees of Tamaulipas]] [[Category:Natural history of the Colorado Desert]] [[Category:Natural history of the Lower Colorado River Valley]] [[Category:Natural history of the Mojave Desert]] [[Category:Flora of Texas]] [[Category:Forages]] [[Category:Plants used in Native American cuisine]]

139.text:
{{Taxobox
| fossil_range = [[Jurassic]] to present
| image =Redwood tree in Oakland California (person for comparison)IMG 4881.jpg
| image_upright = 0.8
| image_caption = Redwoods in [[Oakland, California]]
| regnum = [[Plant]]ae
| divisio = [[Pinophyta]]
| classis = [[Pinopsida]]
| ordo = [[Pinales]]
| familia = [[Cupressaceae]]
| subfamilia = [[Sequoioideae]]
| genus = '''''Sequoia'''''
| genus_authority = [[Stephan Ladislaus Endlicher|Endl.]], conserved name
| subdivision_ranks = [[Species]]
| subdivision = 
*†''[[Sequoia affinis]]''
*†''[[Sequoia chinensis]]''
*†''[[Sequoia dakotensis]]''
*†''[[Sequoia langsdorfii]]''
*†''[[Sequoia magnifica]]''
*''[[Sequoia sempervirens]]''
| synonyms_ref = <ref name=j/>
| synonyms =
*''Condylocarpus'' <small>Salisb. ''ex'' Lamb.</small>
*''Gigantabies'' <small>J.Nelson</small>
}}
[[File:Del_Norte_Titan_230.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Del Norte Titan]], one of the top ten largest coast redwoods – ''[[Sequoia sempervirens]]'']]

'''''Sequoia''''' is a [[genus]] of [[redwood]] [[coniferous tree]]s in the subfamily [[Sequoioideae]] of the family [[Cupressaceae]]. The only [[extant species]] of the genus is ''[[Sequoia sempervirens]]'' in the [[Northern California coastal forests (WWF ecoregion)|Northern California coastal forests ecoregion]] of [[Northern California]] and [[Oregon|Southwestern Oregon]] in the [[United States]].<ref name=j>[http://apps.kew.org/wcsp/namedetail.do?name_id=378988 Kew World Checklist of Selected Plant Families]</ref><ref>[http://bonap.net/MapGallery/County/Sequoia%20sempervirens.png Biota of North America Program 2013 county distribution map]</ref> The two other genera, ''[[Sequoiadendron]]'' and ''[[Metasequoia]]'', in the subfamily Sequoioideae are closely related to ''Sequoia''.  It includes the largest trees in the world.

Several [[extinct]] [[species]] have been named from [[fossil]]s, including ''[[Sequoia affinis]]'', ''[[Sequoia chinensis]]'' of [[China]], ''[[Sequoia langsdorfii]]'', ''[[Sequoia dakotensis]]'' of [[South Dakota]] ([[Maastrichtian]]), and ''[[Sequoia magnifica]]''.

==Etymology==
The name ''Sequoia'' was first published as a genus name by the Austrian botanist [[Stephan Endlicher]] in 1847.<ref>{{cite book|last=Endlicher|first=Stephan|title=Synopsis Coniferarum|publisher=Scheitlin & Zollikofer|location=St. Gallen|date=1847|url=http://biodiversitylibrary.org/page/15191847}}</ref> However, he left no specific reasons for choosing that name, and there is no record of anyone else speaking to him about its origin.

The most common modern guess is that Endlicher, a published linguist as well as a botanist, named the genus in honor of [[Sequoyah]], the inventor of the first [[Cherokee syllabary|Cherokee writing system]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Sierra Nevada - The Naturalist's Companion|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5-8gddnuk-gC&pg=PA55|date=1 June 2000|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0-520-92549-6|page=55}}</ref> As far back as the 1860s, it has also been suggested that the name is instead an alteration of the Latin word for "sequence", since the species is known to be a follower or remnant of massive ancient, extinct species, and thus the next in a sequence.<ref name="Lowe 2012" />

However, in a 2012 article, author Gary Lowe argues that Endlicher would not have had the knowledge to conceive of ''Sequoia sempervirens'' as the successor to a fossil sequence, and that he more likely saw it as completing a [[morphology (biology)|morphological]] sequence of species in regards to seeds per cone scale.<ref name="Lowe 2012">{{cite journal|last=Lowe|first=Gary D.|year=2012|title=Endlicher's sequence: the naming of the genus ''Sequoia''|journal=Fremontia|volume=40| issue =  1 & 2|pages=25–35|url=http://www.cnps.org/cnps/publications/fremontia/FremontiaV40.1_40.2.pdf|format=[[Portable Document Format|PDF]]|accessdate=January 1, 2014}}</ref>

==Paleontology==
The genus ''Sequoia'' first appears in the fossil record as ''[[Sequoia jeholensis]]'', found in [[Jurassic]] deposits of [[South Manchuria]].<ref name="Ahuja">{{cite journal |author=M. R. Ahuja & D. B. Neale |year=2002 |title=Origins of polyploidy in coast redwood (''Sequoia sempervirens'') and relationship of coast redwood to other genera of Taxodiaceae |journal=[[Silvae Genetica]] |volume=51 |issue=2–3 |pages=93–100 |url=http://www.savetheredwoods.org/media/pdf_ahuja.pdf |format=PDF}}</ref> By the late [[Cretaceous]] it was already established in [[Europe]], parts of [[China]], and western [[North America]]. Comparisons among fossils and modern organisms suggest that by this period ''Sequoia'' had already evolved a greater [[tracheid]] diameter that allowed it to reach the great heights characteristic of the modern ''[[Sequoia sempervirens]]'' (coast redwood).

''Sequoia'' was not dominant in the tropical high northern latitudes, like ''[[Metasequoia]]'', a redwood whose [[deciduous]] habit gave it a significant adaptive advantage in an environment with 3 months of continuous darkness.<ref>{{cite book |author=Richard Jagels & Maria A. Equiza |chapter=Competitive advantages of ''Metasequoia'' in warm high latitudes |pages=335–349 |editor=Ben A. LePage, Christopher James Williams & Hong Yang |publisher=[[Springer Science+Business Media|Springer]] |year=2005 |isbn=1-4020-2631-5 |title=The Geobiology and Ecology of ''Metasequoia'' |volume=22 |series=Topics in geobiology |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JfiWU-1GSqEC |location=[[Dordrecht]], the Netherlands}}</ref> However, there still was prolonged range overlap between ''Sequoia'' and ''Metasequoia'' which could have led to hybridization events that created the modern [[hexaploid]] ''Sequoia sempervirens''.<ref name="Ahuja"/><ref name="Rogers">{{cite journal |author=Deborah L. Rogers |year=2000 |title=Genotypic diversity and clone size in old-growth populations of coast redwood (''Sequoia sempervirens'') |journal=[[Canadian Journal of Botany]] |volume=78 |issue=11 |pages=1408–1419 |doi=10.1139/cjb-78-11-1408}}</ref>

A general cooling trend by the late [[Eocene]] and [[Oligocene]] reduced the northern ranges of ''Sequoia''. By the end of the [[Miocene]] and beginning of the [[Pliocene]], ''Sequoia'' fossils were morphologically identical to the modern ''Sequoia sempervirens''.<ref name="Ahuja"/> Continued cooling in the Pliocene meant that ''Sequoia'', which is extremely intolerant to frost due to the high water content of its tissues, also became locally extinct in response to the extreme cooling of Europe and Asia<ref name="Snyder">{{cite thesis |author=James Arthur Snyder |year=1992 |title=The ecology of ''Sequoia sempervirens'': an addendum to "On the edge: nature's last stand for coast redwoods" |publisher=[[San Jose State University]] |degree=[[Master of Arts|M.A.]] |url=http://scholarworks.sjsu.edu/etd_theses/508}}</ref> In western North America it continued to move south through coastal [[Oregon]] and [[California]], surviving due to the abundant rainfall and mild seasons.<ref name="Snyder"/> The [[Sierra Nevada (U.S.)|Sierra Nevada]] [[orogeny]] further isolated ''Sequoia'' because the snowy mountain peaks prevented eastward expansion.<ref name="Snyder"/> The [[Pleistocene]] and [[Holocene]] distributions are likely nearly identical to the modern ''S. sempervirens'' distributions.
