'''''Washingtonia filifera''''', also known as '''desert fan palm'''<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Cornett|first1=J. W.|title=The Common Name of Washingtonia filifera|journal=Principes|date=1986|volume=30|issue=4|pages=153–155}}</ref>, '''California fan palm''' or '''California palm''',<ref>Griffin, Bruce (2000). ''A Natural History of the Sonoran Desert''. University of California Press. Page 165. ISBN 9780520219809.</ref><ref>Kearney, Thomas and Robert Hibbs Peebles (1960). ''Arizona Flora''. University of California Press. Page 164. ISBN 9780520006379.</ref><ref>Flora of North America Association. ''Flora of North America: North of Mexico Volume 22: Magnoliophyta: Alismatidae, Arecidae, Commelinidae(in Part), and Zingiberidae''. Page 106. ISBN 9780195137293.</ref> is a [[flowering plant]] in the palm [[family (biology)|family]] ([[Arecaceae]]), and [[native plant|native]] to the southwestern U.S. and Baja California. Growing to {{convert|15|-|20|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} tall by {{convert|3|-|6|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} broad, it is an [[evergreen]] [[monocot]] with a [[tree]]-like growth habit. It has a sturdy columnar trunk and waxy fan-shaped ([[palmate]]) leaves.
[[File:Washingtonia filifera in Palm Canyon.jpg|thumb|250px|''Washingtonia filifera'' in Palm Canyon, [[Santa Rosa and San Jacinto Mountains National Monument]].]]
[[File:Washingtoniafilifera.JPG|thumb|250px|''Washingtonia filifera'' [[frond]] with fibrous threads on leaf segments.]]
[[File:Washingtonia filifera Anza-Borrego.jpg|thumb|250px|Washingtonia filifera trees and [[fronds]] in [[Anza-Borrego Desert State Park]]]]

==Names==
Other common names include '''California fan palm''' and '''petticoat palm'''.
The [[Botanical name#Binary name|specific epithet]] ''filifera'' means "thread-bearing".

==Distribution==
''Washingtonia filifera'' is the only palm native to the Western United States and the country's largest native palm.<ref name="Hogan">{{cite web | url=http://www.igoterra.com/artspec_information.asp?thingid=90942 | title=California Fan Palm (''Washingtonia filifera'') | publisher=iGoTerra | date=2009-01-05 | accessdate=20 June 2014 | author=Hogan, C. Michael}}</ref><ref name="Clover1937">{{cite journal | title=Vegetational survey of the lower Rio Grand Valley, Texas | author=Clover, E.U. | journal=Madroño |date=April 1937  | volume=4 | issue=2 | pages=41–66 | jstor=41422215}}</ref>

Primary populations are found in desert riparian habitats at spring-fed and stream-fed oases in the [[Colorado Desert]]<ref>{{cite book|last1=Cornett|first1=James W.|title=The Sonoran Desert: A Brief Natural History|date=1997|publisher=Palm Springs Desert Museum|location=Palm Springs, California|isbn=0-937794-27-9}}</ref> and at a few scattered locations in the [[Mojave Desert]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Cornett|first1=James W.|title=Naturalized Populations of the Desert Fan Palm, Washingtonia filifera, in Death Valley National Monument in Plant Biology of Eastern California|date=1987|publisher=White Mountain Research Station, University of California, Los Angeles|location=Los Angeles, California|pages=167–174}}</ref> It is also found near watercourses in the [[Sonoran Desert]] along the [[Gila River]] in [[Yuma, Arizona|Yuma]],<ref>{{Cite web | url=http://www.azcentral.com/story/news/local/phoenix-contributor/2016/03/22/palm-trees-native-arizona/82106610/ | title=Are palm trees native to Arizona? | author=Mark Nothaft | date=March 22, 2016 | access-date=March 26, 2016 | quote=Mark Fleming, curator of botany at the Arizona-Sonora Desert Museum of Tucson, says Washingtonia filifera, or the California fan palm, is the state's only naturally occurring variety and that they are found in pockets around southern California, Northern Mexico and one or two pockets in Arizona.}}</ref> along the [[Hassayampa River]] and near New River in [[Maricopa County, Arizona|Maricopa County]], and in portions of [[Pima County]], [[Pinal County]], [[Mohave County]] (along the Colorado River) and several other isolated locations in [[Clark County, Nevada|Clark County]], Nevada. It is a [[Introduced species|naturalized]] species in the warm springs near [[Death Valley]] and in the extreme northwest of [[Sonora]] (Mexico). It is also reportedly naturalized in the [[Southeastern United States|Southeast]], [[Florida]], [[Hawaii]], the U.S. [[Virgin Islands]], and [[Australia]] ([[New South Wales]]).<ref name="USDA">{{cite web | url=http://plants.usda.gov/core/profile?symbol=WAFI | title=Plant Profile for Washingtonia filifera (California fan palm) | publisher=[[United States Department of Agriculture]] | work=Natural Resources Conservation Service | accessdate=20 June 2014}}</ref><ref name="WCSP">{{cite web | url=http://apps.kew.org/wcsp/namedetail.do?name_id=214250 | title=Washingtonia filifera (Rafarin) H.Wendl. ex de Bary, Bot. Zeitung (Berlin) 37: LXI (1879). | work=World Checklist of Selected Plant Families | accessdate=21 June 2014 | author=Govaerts, R.}}</ref>

==Description==
{{Refimprove section|date=June 2014}}
''Washingtonia filifera'' grows to {{convert|18|m|ft}} in height (occasionally to {{convert|25|m|ft}}) in ideal conditions. The California Fan Palm Tree is also known as the Desert Fan Palm, American Cotton Palm and Arizona Fan Palm.

The [[frond]]s are up to {{convert|3.5|- |4|m|ft}} long, made up of a [[Petiole (botany)|petiole]] up to {{convert|2|m|ft}} long, bearing a fan of leaflets {{convert|1.5|-|2|m|ft}} long. They have long thread-like white fibers and the petioles are pure green with yellow edges and ''filifera''-filaments, between the segments. The trunk is gray and tan and the leaves are gray green. When the fronds die they remain attached and drop down to cloak the trunk in a wide skirt. The shelter that the skirt creates provides a microhabitat for many small birds and invertebrates. If there is any red color present on petioles or trunk it is not a pure filifera but a fila-busta hybrid.

''Washingtonia filifera'' can live from 80 to 250 years or more.

==Ecology==
Desert fan palms provide habitat for the giant palm boring beetle, western yellow bat, hooded oriole and many other bird species. Hooded orioles rely on the trees for food and places to build nests. Numerous insect species visit the hanging inflorescences that appear in late spring.<ref>Cornett, J. W. 1986. Arthropod visitors at Washingtonia filifera (Wendl) Flowers. Pan Pacific Entomologist 62(3):224-225.</ref>

===Threats===
The palm boring beetle ''[[Dinapate wrightii]]'' ([[Bostrichidae]]) can chew through the trunks of this as well as other palms. Eventually a continued infestation of beetles can kill various genera and species of palms. The recent discovery of the red palm weevil (''[[Rhynchophorus ferrugineus]]'') in Southern California may pose a threat to many palms, with coastal garden ''W. filifera'' specimens already a known host.<ref name="OCRegister">{{cite news | url=http://www.ocregister.com/news/palm-269513-nisson-tree.html | title=Destructive exotic beetle found in Laguna Beach | work=Orange County Register | date=2010-10-04 | accessdate=20 June 2014 | author=Koerner, Claudia | location=Santa Ana, California}}</ref> However, it seems that this species is resistant to the red palm weevil through a mechanism based on [[antibiosis]].<ref name="CISR">{{cite web | url=http://cisr.ucr.edu/red_palm_weevil.html | title=Red Palm Weevil | publisher=[[University of California Riverside]] | work=Center for Invasive Species Research | accessdate=20 June 2014 | last1=Nisson | last2=Hodel | last3=Hoddle | first1=N. | first2=D. | first3=M.}}</ref><ref name="Dembilio2009">{{cite journal | title=Are the palms ''Washingtonia filifera'' and ''Chamaerops humilis'' suitable hosts for the red palm weevil, ''Rhynchophorus ferrugineus'' (Col. Curculionidae)? | journal=Journal of Applied Entomology |date=August 2009  | volume=133 | issue=7 | pages=565–567 | doi=10.1111/j.1439-0418.2009.01385.x | last1=Dembilio | last2=Jacas | last3=Llácer | first1=Ó. | first2=J.A. | first3=E.}}</ref>

Currently the desert fan palm is experiencing a population and range expansion, perhaps due to global warming.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Cornett|first1=James W.|title=Desert Palm Oasis|date=2010|publisher=Nature Trails Press|location=Palm Springs, California|isbn=978-0-937794-42-5|edition=Second}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.xeri.com/Moapa/globalwarm.htm|title=global warming & W.filifera Palms-a rebuttal|website=www.xeri.com|access-date=2016-12-10}}</ref>

==History==

Historically, natural oases are mainly restricted to areas downstream from the source of hot springs, though water is not always visible at the surface.

Grazing animals can kill young plants through trampling, or by eating the terminus at the apical meristem, the growing portion of the plant. This may have kept palms restricted to a lesser range than indicated by the availability of water.

Today's oasis environment may have been protected from colder climatic changes over the course of its evolution. Thus this palm is restricted by both water and climate to widely separated [[relict]] groves.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.xeri.com/Moapa/relict.htm|title=Desert Fan Palms-Evidence suggests "Relict Genus"|website=www.xeri.com|access-date=2016-12-10}}</ref> The trees in these groves show little if any genetic differentiation, (through electrophoretic examination) suggesting that the genus is genetically very stable.

==Access==
[[Joshua Tree National Park]] in the Mojave Desert preserves and protects healthy riparian palm habitat examples in the Little San Bernardino Mountains, and westward where water rises through the San Andreas Fault on the east valley side. In the central Coachella Valley the [[Indio Hills Palms|Indio Hills Palms State Reserve]] and nearby [[Coachella Valley National Wildlife Refuge|Coachella Valley Preserve]], other large oases are protected and accessible. The [[Santa Rosa and San Jacinto Mountains National Monument]], and [[Anza-Borrego Desert State Park]] both have large and diverse ''W. filifera'' canyon oasis habitats.

==Native Americans==
The fruit of the fan palm was eaten raw, cooked, or ground into flour for cakes.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Cornett|first1=James W.|title=Indian Uses of Desert Plants|date=2011|publisher=Nature Trails Press|location=Palm Springs, California|isbn=978-0-937794-45-6|edition=Third}}</ref> The Cahuilla and related tribes used the leaves to make sandals, thatch roofs, and baskets. The stems were used to make cooking utensils. The Moapa band of Paiutes as well as other Southern Paiutes have written memories of using this palm's seed, fruit or leaves for various purposes including starvation food.<ref name="Spencer_Foreword">{{cite web | url=http://www.xeri.com/Moapa/wf-hr-foreword.htm | title=Washingtonia filifera:  Nevada's rejected ancient Palm. | publisher=www.xeri.com | date=1995 | accessdate=21 June 2014 | author=Spencer, W.}}</ref><ref name="SpencerPartOne">{{cite web | url=http://www.xeri.com/Moapa/wf-hr-part1.htm | title=A report regarding: The Palm - Washingtonia filifera - in Moapa NV | publisher=www.xeri.com | date=1995 | accessdate=21 June 2014 | author=Spencer, W.}}</ref>

==Cultivation==
[[File:Attica 06-13 Athens 12 National Garden.jpg|thumb|Palms planted 1834 by [[Amalia of Greece]] in Athens ([[National Garden, Athens|National Garden]])]]
''Washingtonia filifera'' is widely cultivated as an [[ornamental tree]]. It is one of the hardiest Coryphoidiae palms, rated as hardy to USDA [[hardiness zone]] 8. It will survive brief temperatures of {{convert|-10|°C|°F}} with minor damage, and established plants have survived, with severe leaf damage, brief periods as low as {{convert|-12|°C|°F}}. The plants grow best in Mediterranean climates, but can be found in humid subtropical climates like eastern Australia and the southeastern USA.

''Washingtonia filifera'' has gained the [[Royal Horticultural Society]]'s [[Award of Garden Merit]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://apps.rhs.org.uk/plantselector/plant?plantid=2037 | title=''Washingtonia filifera'': Washington palm | publisher=Royal Horticultural Society | work=RHS Gardening | accessdate=21 June 2014}}</ref>

{{Taxobox | name = Western white pine
''Pinus monticola'' | status = NT | status_system = IUCN3.1 | status_ref = {{IUCN | id = 42383| taxon = ''Pinus monticola''| assessor = Farjon, A.| assessment_year = 2011| version = 3.1| criteria-version = 3.1| accessdate = 2013-11-10}} | image = Pinus monticola Idaho3.jpg | image_caption = Western white pine (center) | regnum = [[Plantae]] | divisio = [[Pinophyta]] | classis = [[Pinopsida]] | ordo = [[Pinales]] | familia = [[Pinaceae]] | genus = ''[[Pinus]]'' | subgenus = ''[[Pinus classification|Strobus]]'' | species = '''''P. monticola''''' | binomial = ''Pinus monticola'' | binomial_authority = [[David Douglas (botanist)|Douglas]] ex [[D. Don]] | range_map = Pinus monticola range map 1.png }} '''Western white pine''' ('''''Pinus monticola''''') also called '''silver pine''',{{cite web|url=http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/taxon.pl?28491|title=USDA GRIN Taxonomy}} and '''California mountain pine''', in the family [[Pinaceae]], is a species of [[pine]] that occurs in the mountains of the western [[United States]] and [[Canada]], specifically the [[Sierra Nevada (U.S.)|Sierra Nevada]], the [[Cascade Range]], the [[Pacific Coast Ranges|Coast Range]], and the northern [[Rocky Mountains]]. The tree extends down to sea level in many areas, particularly in Oregon and Washington. It is the [[List of U.S. state trees|state tree]] of [[Idaho]], and is sometimes known as the '''Idaho pine'''.{{cite book |author1=Moore, Gerry |author2=Kershner, Bruce |author3=Craig Tufts |author4=Daniel Mathews |author5=Gil Nelson |author6=Spellenberg, Richard |author7=Thieret, John W. |author8=Terry Purinton |author9=Block, Andrew |title=National Wildlife Federation Field Guide to Trees of North America |publisher=Sterling |location=New York |year=2008 |page=78 |isbn=1-4027-3875-7}} ==Description== [[File:Pinus monticola0.jpg|thumb|left|Foliage and cones]] Western white pine (''Pinus monticola'') is a large [[tree]], regularly growing to {{convert|30|–|50|m|ft}} and exceptionally up to {{convert|70|m|ft}} tall. It is a member of the [[Pinus classification|white pine]] group, ''[[Pinus]]'' subgenus ''[[Strobus]]'', and like all members of that group, the leaves ('needles') are in [[Fascicle (botany)|fascicles]] (bundles) of five, with a deciduous sheath. The needles are finely serrated, and {{convert|5|–|13|cm|in}} long. The cones are long and slender, {{convert|12|–|32|cm|in}} long and {{convert|3|–|4|cm|in}} broad (closed), opening to {{convert|5|–|8|cm|in}} broad; the scales are thin and flexible. The seeds are small, 4–7 mm long, and have a long slender wing 15–22 mm long. It is related to the [[Eastern white pine]] (''Pinus strobus''), differing from it in having larger cones, slightly longer-lasting leaves (2–3 years, rather than 1.5–2 years) with more prominent [[stoma]]tal bands, and a somewhat denser and narrower habit. The branches are borne in regular whorls, produced at the rate of one a year; this is pronounced in narrow, stand-grown trees, while open specimens may have a more rounded form with wide-reaching limbs. It is widely grown as an [[ornamental tree]], but has been heavily logged throughout much of its range in the past. ==Threats== [[File:Pinus monticola Umatilla.jpg|thumb|left|230px|Large ''P. monticola'']] Western white pine (''Pinus monticola'') has been seriously affected by the [[Cronartium ribicola|white pine blister rust]] (''Cronartium ribicola''), a fungus that was accidentally introduced from [[Europe]] in 1909. The [[United States Forest Service]] estimates that 90% of the Western white pines have been killed by the blister rust west of the [[Cascade Range|Cascades]]. Large stands have been succeeded by other pines or non-pine species. The rust has also killed much of the [[Whitebark pine]] outside of [[California]]. Blister rust is less severe in California, and Western white and whitebark pines have survived there in great numbers. Resistance to the blister rust is genetic, and due to Western white pine's genetic variability some individuals are relatively unaffected by the rust. The Forest Service has a program for locating and breeding rust-resistant Western white pine and [[sugar pine]]. Seedlings of these trees have been introduced into the wild. {{clear|left}} [[File:Western white pine.jpg|thumb|right|230px|Western white pine in [[St. Joe National Forest]]. Died in 1998 and was cut down in 1999.]] ==References== {{reflist}} *[http://www.fs.fed.us/r6/dorena/ US Forest Service Dorena Tree Improvement Center] ==Further reading== * {{cite book | last1 = Chase| first1 = J. Smeaton| authorlink1 = J. Smeaton Chase| title = Cone-bearing Trees of the California Mountains | location = Chicago | publisher = [[A. C. McClurg & Co.]] | pages = 99 | isbn = |year=1911 | oclc = 3477527|lccn=11004975}} {{LCC|QK495.C75 C4}}, with illustrations by [[Carl Eytel]] - [http://www.cslfdn.org/pdf/bulletin-95.pdf Kurut, Gary F. (2009), "Carl Eytel: Southern California Desert Artist", ''California State Library Foundation'', Bulletin No. 95, pp. 17-20] retrieved Nov. 13, 2011 ==External links== {{Commons|Pinus monticola}} *[http://plants.usda.gov/java/profile?symbol=PIMO3 USDA: ''Pinus monticola''] *[http://ucjeps.berkeley.edu/cgi-bin/get_JM_treatment.pl?195,210,227 Jepson Manual treatment - ''Pinus monticola''] *[http://calphotos.berkeley.edu/cgi/img_query?query_src=photos_index&where-taxon=Pinus+monticola ''Pinus monticola'' - U.C. Photos Gallery] [[Category:Flora of the Sierra Nevada (U.S.)]] [[Category:Least concern flora of California]] [[Category:Least concern flora of the United States]] [[Category:Pinus]] [[Category:Symbols of Idaho]] [[Category:Trees of Alberta]] [[Category:Trees of British Columbia]] [[Category:Trees of the Southwestern United States]] [[Category:Trees of the Northwestern United States]]

{{redirect|Joshua Tree|the U2 album|The Joshua Tree|the national park|Joshua Tree National Park|the town|Joshua Tree, California|other uses}}
{{Speciesbox
|taxon = Yucca brevifolia
|name = Joshua tree 
|image = Joshua Tree 01.jpg
|image_caption = In Joshua Tree National Park, California
|authority = [[George Engelmann|Engelm.]]
|synonyms = *''Clistoyucca brevifolia'' <small>(Engelm.) Rydb.</small>
*''Sarcoyucca brevifolia'' <small>(Engelm.) Linding.</small>
*''Yucca arborescens'' <small>(Torr.) Trel.</small>
*''Yucca jaegeriana'' <small>(McKelvey) L.W.Lenz</small>
*''Yucca brevifolia'' subsp. ''jaegeriana'' <small>(McKelvey) Hochstätter</small>
*''Yucca brevifolia'' var. ''jaegerana'' <small>McKelvey </small>
*''Cleistoyucca arborescens'' <small>(Torr.) Eastw.</small>
*''Clistoyucca arborescens'' <small>(Torr.) Trel.</small>
*''Yucca arborescens'' <small>(Torr.) Trel.</small>
*''Yucca brevifolia'' var. ''herbertii'' <small>(J.M. Webber) Munz</small>
*''Yucca brevifolia'' fo. ''herbertii'' <small>J.M. Webber  </small>
*''Yucca brevifolia'' subsp. ''herbertii'' <small>(J.M. Webber) Hochstätter</small>
*''Yucca brevifolia'' var. ''jaegerana'' <small>McKelvey</small>
*''Yucca draconis'' var. ''arborescens'' <small>Torr.</small>
|synonyms_ref = <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tropicos.org/name/18401424|publisher=Tropicos|title=Yucca brevifolia}}</ref>
|range_map =  Yucca brevifolia range map.jpg
|range_map_caption = Natural range
}}

'''''Yucca brevifolia''''' is a plant species belonging to the genus ''[[Yucca]]''. It is tree-like in habit, which is reflected in its common names: '''Joshua tree''', '''yucca palm''', '''tree yucca''', and '''palm tree yucca'''.<ref name="Gucker 2006">{{cite web|last1=Gucker|first1=Corey L.|year=2006|url=http://www.fs.fed.us/database/feis/plants/tree/yucbre/all.html|title=Yucca brevifolia|work=Fire Effects Information System|publisher=[[U.S. Department of Agriculture]], Forest Service, Rocky Mountain Research Station, Fire Sciences Laboratory|accessdate=2008-12-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://bioimages.vanderbilt.edu/metadata.htm?/565605/metadata/sp|title=Yucca brevifolia|work=BioImages|publisher=Vanderbilt University |accessdate=2014-12-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.delange.org/JoshuaTree/JoshuaTree.htm |title=Joshua Tree, Yucca brevifolia|work=Arizona Wild Flowers|publisher=Delange |accessdate=2012-03-30}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.botanicus.org/page/899141|last=Watson|first=Sereno|year=1871|title=United States Geological Exploration of the Fortieth Parallel|volume=5|issue=464|journal=Botany|page=496|bibcode=1878Natur..18..538J|doi=10.1038/018538a0}}</ref>

This [[monocotyledon]]ous [[tree]] is native to the arid southwestern [[United States]], specifically [[California]], [[Arizona]], [[Utah]], and [[Nevada]], where it is confined mostly to the [[Mojave Desert]] between {{convert|400|and|1,800|m|ft|abbr=on}} elevation. It thrives in the open grasslands of [[Queen Valley (Joshua Tree National Park)|Queen Valley]] and [[Lost Horse Valley]] in [[Joshua Tree National Park]]. A dense Joshua tree forest also exists in [[Mojave National Preserve]], in the [[Cima Dome]], ([[Cima, California]]), northeast of Kingman, Arizona in Mohave County, Arizona, as well as along U.S. 93 between the towns of Wickenburg and Wikieup, and designated as the Joshua Tree Parkway of Arizona.

==Taxonomy==
The name ''Joshua tree'' was given by a group of [[Mormon]] settlers crossing the Mojave Desert in the mid-19th century. The tree's unique shape reminded them of a [[Bible|Biblical]] story in which [[Joshua]] reaches his hands up to the sky in prayer.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.nps.gov/jotr/naturescience/jtrees.htm |work= Nature and Science: Joshua Trees |title= Joshua Tree National Park |publisher= [[National Park Service]]|accessdate= 2013-05-27 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://travel.nationalgeographic.com/travel/national-parks/joshua-tree-national-park/ |title= Joshua Tree National Park |publisher= [[National Geographic Society]] |accessdate= 2013-05-27 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.usanpn.org/cpp/YUBR |title= Joshua Tree (Yucca brevifolia) |work=  Meet the Species: All Species |publisher= The California Phenology Project, USA National Phenology Network |accessdate= 2013-05-27 }}</ref> Ranchers and miners who were contemporary with the Mormon immigrants used the trunks and branches as fencing and for fuel for ore-processing steam engines. It is also called ''izote de desierto'' (Spanish, "desert dagger").<ref name=ITIS>{{cite web|url=http://www.itis.gov/servlet/SingleRpt/SingleRpt?search_topic=TSN&search_value=43116|title=Yucca|work=Itis Report|publisher=Integrated Taxonomic Information System|accessdate=2012-03-30}}</ref> It was first formally described in the botanical literature as ''Yucca brevifolia'' by [[George Engelmann]] in 1871 as part of the Geological Exploration of the 100th meridian or [[Wheeler Survey]].<ref name="IPNI">{{cite web|work=International Plant Names Index|url=http://www.ipni.org/ipni/idPlantNameSearch.do?id=543655-1&back_page=%2Fipni%2FeditSimplePlantNameSearch.do%3Ffind_wholeName%3DYucca%2Bbrevifolia%26output_format%3Dnormal|title=''Yucca brevifolia'' Engelm.|accessdate=2008-12-20}}</ref>

In addition to the [[Autonym (botany)|autonymic]] [[subspecies]] ''Yucca brevifolia'' subsp. ''brevifolia'', two other subspecies have been described:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.yuccaagavaceae.com/species.html |title=Yucca species |publisher=Yuccaagavaceae.com |accessdate=2012-03-30}}</ref> ''Yucca brevifolia'' subsp. ''jaegeriana'' (the Jaeger Joshua tree or Jaeger's Joshua tree or pygmae yucca) and ''Yucca brevifolia'' subsp. ''herbertii'' (Webber's yucca or Herbert Joshua tree), though both are sometimes treated as varieties<ref name=ITIS/><ref name=Grandtner2005>{{Cite book| last = Grandtner | first = Miroslav M.| year = 2005| title = Elsevier's Dictionary of Trees - North America| page = 973| url = https://books.google.com/?id=yjc5ZYWtkNAC&pg=PA973&dq=Yucca+brevifolia| isbn = 0-444-51784-7| publisher = Elsevier | location = Amsterdam
}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cnpsci.org/html/PlantInfo/ChecklistofVenturaCountyRarePlants-19Sep2005.pdf |title=Checklist of Ventura County Rare Plants |format=PDF |publisher=California National Plant Society, Channel Islands Chapter|first=David L.|last=Magney|date=2005-09-19|accessdate=2012-03-30}}</ref> or forms.<ref name=Egglid2001>{{cite book | last = Eggli | first =  Urs | year = 2001 | title = Monocotyledons  | pages = 90–91, 100 | isbn = 978-3-540-41692-0 | publisher = Springer | location = Berlin }}</ref>

==Growth and development==

Joshua trees are fast growers for the desert; new seedlings may grow at an average rate of {{convert|7.6|cm|in|1|abbr=on}} per year in their first ten years, then only about {{convert|3.8|cm|in|1|abbr=on}} per year.<ref name="Keith 1982">{{cite journal | last1 = Keith | first1 = Sandra L | year = 1982 | title = A tree named Joshua | url = | journal = American Forests | volume = 88 | issue = 7| pages = 40–42 }}</ref> The trunk consists of thousands of small [[fiber]]s and lacks annual [[growth ring]]s, making it difficult to determine the tree's age. This tree has a top-heavy branch system, but also what has been described as a "deep and extensive" root system, with roots reaching up to {{convert|11|m|ft|0|abbr=on}}.<ref name="Gucker 2006" /> If it survives the rigors of the desert, it can live for hundreds of years; some specimens survive a thousand years. The tallest trees reach about {{convert|15|m|ft|0|abbr=on}}. New plants can grow from [[seed]], but in some populations, new stems grow from underground [[rhizome]]s that spread out around the parent tree.

The [[evergreen]] [[leaf|leaves]] are dark green, linear, bayonet-shaped, 15–35 cm long and 7–15 mm broad at the base, tapering to a sharp point; they are borne in a dense spiral arrangement at the apex of the stems. The leaf margins are white and [[serrate]].
[[File:Joshua Tree Panicle 1.jpg|thumb|left|Flowers grow in [[panicle]]s]]

[[Flower]]s appear from February to late April, in [[panicle]]s 30–55 cm tall and 30–38 cm broad, the individual flowers erect, 4–7 cm tall, with six creamy white to green [[tepal]]s. The tepals are [[lanceolate]] and are fused to the middle. The fused [[pistil]]s are 3 cm tall and the stigma cavity is surrounded by lobes. The semi-fleshy fruit that is produced is green-brown, elliptical, and contains many flat seeds. Joshua trees usually do not branch until after they bloom (though branching may also occur if the growing tip is destroyed by the yucca-boring [[weevil]]), and they do not bloom every year. Like most desert plants, their blooming depends on rainfall at the proper time. They also need a winter freeze before they bloom.

Once they bloom, the trees are pollinated by the [[yucca moth]], which spreads pollen while laying her eggs inside the flower. The [[moth]] [[larva]]e feed on the seeds of the tree, but enough seeds are left behind to produce more trees. The Joshua tree is also able to actively abort ovaries in which too many eggs have been laid.

==Distribution and habitat==

''Yucca brevifolia'' is [[endemism|endemic]] to the [[Southwestern United States]] with populations in western [[Arizona]], southeastern [[California]], southern [[Nevada]], and southwestern [[Utah]]. This range mostly coincides with the geographical reach of the [[Mojave Desert]],<ref name="Gucker 2006" /> where it is considered one of the major [[indicator species]] for the desert. It occurs at altitudes between {{convert|400|and|1,800|m|ft|abbr=on}}.<ref name="Gossard 1992">{{cite book|last=Gossard|first=G|year=1992|title=The Joshua Tree, a Controversial, Contradictory Desert Centurion|publisher=Yellow Rose Publications}}</ref>

===Conservation status===

In a 2001 paper  published in the journal ''Ecosystems'', Joshua trees are one of the species predicted to have their range reduced and shifted by [[climate change]].<ref name=ShafBartThom01>{{Cite journal |last=Shafer |first=Sarah L. |last2=Bartlein |first2=Patrick J. |last3=Thompson |first3=Robert S. |year=2001 |title=Potential changes in the distributions of western North America tree and shrub taxa under future climate scenarios |journal=Ecosystems |volume=4 |issue=3 |pages=200–215 |url=http://www.springerlink.com/index/8uqf2ebr0l2h9x2w.pdf |accessdate=2013-03-06 |lastauthoramp=yes |doi=10.1007/s10021-001-0004-5}}</ref> There is concern that they will be eliminated from [[Joshua Tree National Park]], with ecological research suggesting a high probability that their populations will be reduced by 90% of their current range by the end of the 21st century,<ref name="Cole2011">{{cite journal|last1=Cole|first1=Kenneth L.|first2=Kirsten|last2=Ironside |first3=Jon|last3=Eischeid |first4=Gregg|last4=Garfin |first5=Phillip B.|last5=Duffy |first6= Chris|last6=Toney |year=2011|title=Past and ongoing shifts in Joshua tree distribution support future modeled range contraction |journal=Ecological Applications|volume=21|issue=1|pages=137–149|url=http://www.fs.fed.us/rm/pubs_other/rmrs_2011_cole_k001.pdf|doi=10.1890/09-1800.1|pmid=21516893}}</ref><ref name=NPR>{{cite web|url=http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=17628032 |title=Outlook Bleak for Joshua Trees |publisher=National Public Radio |date=2008-02-04 |accessdate=2012-03-30}}</ref> thus fundamentally transforming the ecosystem of the park. There is also concern about the ability of the species to migrate to favorable climates due to the extinction of the giant [[Shasta ground sloth]] (''Nothrotheriops shastensis'') 13,000 years ago; ground sloth dung has been found to contain Joshua tree leaves, fruits, and seeds, suggesting that the sloths might have been key to the tree's dispersal.<ref name="Cole2011"/><ref name=NPR/>

== Uses and cultivation ==
[[File:JoshuaTreeFruit 2008-06-19-25.jpg|thumb|right|Fruit]]
Different forms of the species are cultivated, including smaller plants native from the eastern part of the species range. These smaller plants grow 2.5 meters tall and branch when about a meter tall.<ref name=Harlow2003>{{cite book | editor-last1 = Harlow | editor-first1 = Nora| editor-first2 = Kristin |editor-last2=Jakob | year = 2003| title = Wild lilies, irises, and grasses: gardening with California monocots | page = 215| isbn = 978-0-520-23849-7| publisher = [[University of California Press]]| location = Berkeley}}</ref>

[[Cahuilla]] Native Americans, who have lived in the southwestern United States for generations, identify this plant as a valuable resource and call it "hunuvat chiy’a" or "humwichawa". Their ancestors used the leaves of ''Y. brevifolia'' to weave sandals and baskets, in addition to harvesting the seeds and flower buds for meals.

Yucca tree roots have [[Glycoside#Saponins|saponin glycosides]].<ref name=Burdock2005>{{Cite book| last = Burdock | first =  George A. | year = 2005 | title = Fenaroli's handbook of flavor ingredients | page = 1913 | isbn = 0-8493-3034-3 | publisher = CRC Press | location = Boca Raton, Fla.}}</ref>

159.text:
{{taxobox
|image = Ziziphus obtusifolia var canescens 3.jpg
|image_caption =''Ziziphus obtusifolia'' var. ''canescens''
|regnum = [[Plant]]ae
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]]
|ordo = [[Rosales]]
|familia = [[Rhamnaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Ziziphus]]''
|species = '''''Z. obtusifolia'''''
|binomial = ''Ziziphus obtusifolia''
|binomial_authority = ([[William Jackson Hooker|Hook.]] ex [[John Torrey|Torr.]] & [[Asa Gray|A.Gray]]) A. Gray
|}}
'''''Ziziphus obtusifolia''''' is a species of flowering plant in the [[Rhamnaceae|buckthorn family]] known by several common names, including '''lotebush''', '''graythorn''', '''gumdrop tree''', and '''Texas buckthorn'''.<ref name=fs>[http://www.fs.fed.us/database/feis/plants/shrub/zizobt/all.html US Forest Service Fire Ecology]</ref> 

==Distribution==
The plant is native to the South Central and [[Southwestern United States]], the [[California]] deserts, and central through northern [[Mexico]]. <ref>[http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/taxon.pl?105422 NPGS/GRIN information for ''Ziziphus obtusifolia'']</ref>

It grows in shrubby and scrubby [[desert]] habitats, [[grassland]]s and [[prairie]], woodlands, and other habitat types. It can be found among desert plants such as [[Prosopis glandulosa|honey mesquite]], [[Prosopis laevigata|smooth mesquite]], [[Fouquieria splendens|ocotillo]] and [[Larrea tridentata|creosote]].<ref name=fs/> 

==Description==
''Ziziphus obtusifolia'' is a [[shrub]] with many branches forming a thorny tangle which may exceed {{convert|3|m|ft}} tall and approach {{convert|4|m|ft}}  at times. 

The leaves are [[deciduous]] and are absent for much of the year, leaving the shrub a naked thicket of gray twigs coated in waxy whitish hairs. The ends of the twigs taper into sharp-tipped thorns. The thick, glandular gray or green leaves have oval blades 1 or 2 centimeters long. 

The [[inflorescence]] is a cluster of several dull yellow-green flowers. The fruit is a mealy, juicy [[drupe]] containing one seed.

The fruit provides food for many species of birds and mammals.<ref name=fs/> Birds use the shrub as a nesting site and the [[southern plains woodrat]] uses the twigs to build its houses.<ref name=fs/>
